This will include demos and open source templates that can be reused for their own applications.
schedule.problem_addressed: While companies provide many powerful instruction set extensions, it is challenging for developers to generate code that takes advantage of these capabilities. Currently, developers have to either write multiple versions of their code (each targeting different instruction set extensions and manually handle runtime dispatching of these versions) or they can generate multiple versions of their binary (each targeting a different platform).Also, as we’ve seen during the last decade, cloud products are performing tasks we never thought they would, on systems design, the main goal is to obtain the most performance possible which consumes the least power. The natural solution is for the cloud developers to understand and optimize software as much as possible, however due to the complex tasks systems perform nowadays, this has also gotten harder.A solution of these problems is the use of GCC5 latest features
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This presentation will help the cloud developers ( not just Linux OS developers ) to better understand the capabilities of the latest version of GCC compiler and will hopefully encourage them to use them in their cloud projects, giving the users applications with higher performance. We will provide demos and open source templates that can be reused for their own applications.

videos.name: Improving Cloud Performance with GCC Latest Technologies in Clear Linux Project

schedule.title: HPE -  Ignite session: What’s Hot and What’s new
schedule.description:
Ignite is fast and  informative! With 5 minutes per speaker, you’ll hear what’s hot and new in the world of OpenStack at HPE from our experts on:

  • Ironic and Baremetal containers for high performance  workloads
  • Looking under the hood at the routing and integration capabilities of Neutron
  • Providing a single view into the availability and performance of OpenStack clouds with operations dashboard
  • Integrate security at each level with Security Review Process used with HPE Helion

Don’t miss this fun, fast paced and informative cap off to a great track with HPE!

videos.name: HPE -  Ignite session: What’s Hot and What’s new

schedule.title: OpenStack HA, or not HA: That is the Question!
schedule.description: From the operations perspective talking about OpenStack deployments without a HA architecture model for your cloud control plane is the most absurd and non-sense design that an architect could even mention. Actually, discussing such approach in front of your peers architects will led them to believe that you do not have neither the experience nor the knowledge to manage a production cloud.Let’s show them they are wrong by exposing and discussing the Cloud Architecture of one of the SaaS leads in the world with over 200 hypervisor deployed in multiple data center geographically distributed.
schedule.problem_addressed: The goal of this session is to show that a non-HA architecture is an option where the right components for high availability are in place at the networking model. Losing your control plane is not acceptable but having a complicated HA architecture could delay your time to production with a technology as complete as OpenStack is. This session will face the problem of deciding whether building a complex HA architecture will be the best fit for you cloud deployment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The audience will learn how a core and aggregation high availability network design will mitigate any downtimes on your cloud control plane. On the other hand, the use of the proper overlay network technology on the data plane will solve any potential downtimes on the data plane to the point that they can be drastically minimized or even non-expected at all.As attendees you will see and review the cloud design and blueprints from a successful SaaS lead companies and both overlay and underlay networking levels.

videos.name: OpenStack HA, or not HA: That is the Question!

schedule.title: Cephfs as a Service with OpenStack Manila
schedule.description:
Ceph is a popular storage backend for OpenStack deployments, in use for block devices via RBD/Cinder and for object storage with RGW. Ceph also includes a filesystem, CephFS which is suitable for integration with Manila, the OpenStack shared filesystem service.

This presentation introduces the new CephFS Native driver for Manila, describing its the implementation of the driver, and how to deploy and use it. Areas of particular interest for Ceph users will include how CephFS snapshots map to Manila's snapshot API, how Ceph's authentication scheme can be used with Manila.

In addition, the direction of future work will be described, including how the driver can be extended to provide an NFS share service based on CephFS, and how this work would integrate with VSOCK-based hypervisor-mediated filesystem access.
schedule.problem_addressed: Users with applications requiring a shared filesystem currently have limited options with Manila, since the previous fully-featured Manila drivers required external storage appliances.  Users with existing Ceph clusters in used for RBD will be interested in using CephFS/Manila to provide their applications a shared filesystem capability using the same open source storage cluster as their disk image store.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn:

 * What the CephFS Manila driver is, and how it works.

 * How they can set up a CephFS/Manila deployment themselves

 * The caveats and limitations of the initial CephFS driver

 * What feature developments they can look for in CephFS/Manila in the future

videos.name: Cephfs as a Service with OpenStack Manila

schedule.title: Continuous Compliance & Enforcement of Location-Based Policies in an OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description:
Study after study shows that security is still the biggest barrier to cloud adoption, with compliance and data protection being top concerns for a CISO.    

Enterprises often have a need to enforce policies (based on data sovereignty requirements) such as virtual workloads should only be placed, or migrated, based on location and assurance of hardware platform. 

Some others  want to launch VMs/Apps/Containers on Servers with Boot Integrity – Platform Trust, while some have a need to extend the chain of trust from platform to workload (VM/Container). This session features a customer case study from Visa with technologies from Intel (CIT, TXT and TPM), HPE (Helion OpenStack and Proliant Gen 9 server) and Cloud Raxak (RaxakProtect) that demonstrates end-to-end compliance (boot time to shutdown) using hardware and software attestations.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Study after study shows that security is still the biggest barrier to cloud adoption, with compliance and data protection being top concerns for a CSO or CIO.    

Enterprises often have a need to enforce policies (based on data sovereignty requirements) such workloads should only be placed, or migrated, based on location and assurance of hardware platform.  

This session features a customer case study with technologies from Intel (CIT, TXT and TPM), HPE (Helion OpenStack and Proliant Gen 9 server) and Cloud Raxak (RaxakProtect) that demonstrates the following use cases:

  • Achieving end-to-end compliance
  • Checking and enforcing policies for configuration and compliance drifts
  • Reporting a trust status for compliance auditing
  • Creating/enforcing security policies to run/migrate workloads based on trusted compute pools
  • Creating/enforcing security policies based on geo-fencing capabilities
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can expect to learn how a combination of technologies from vendors like Intel, HPE and Cloud Raxak can solve the problem of enforcing security policies (such as the ability to run/migrate workloads only on trusted VMs) based on hardware and software attestations as well as geo-locations, in an OpenStack cloud environment.  

 

This is critical for meeting compliance requirements and data sovereignty rules.

videos.name: Continuous Compliance & Enforcement of Location-Based Policies in an OpenStack Cloud

schedule.title: How to Integrate OpenStack Swift to Your "Legacy" System
schedule.description:
OpenStack Swift is a storage project in OpenStack, which realizes a highly scalable and robust object storage, with low operational cost.

We, cloud storage team in NTT DATA, have been offered many projects aiming to replace legacy storage to swift, to store more data more safely with lower cost. In those project, we were often required not to change the existing systems. However, this requirement causes a problem in our integration, when they are so "legacy" that they rarely support REST API. Many systems are still on the way to turning to cloud-native architectures (like REST API), and we have seen many demands to introduce cloud system into no-cloud system, as the first step for ther turning.

In this session, we will explain some example cases from our Swift projects and how we solved this interface problem to intergrate Swift, very useful cloud technology, into the existing "legacy" systems.
schedule.problem_addressed: System integration between the existing system which doesn't support REST API and swift which only supports REST API.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
- Example of user requirement and solution about integrating legacy system and Swift

- Some basic points and ideas to integrate Swift into existing systems

videos.name: How to Integrate OpenStack Swift to Your "Legacy" System

schedule.title: Using Open Source Security Architecture to Defend against Targeted Attacks
schedule.description:
A network IPS can effectively defend your OpenStack cloud against targeted attacks, even at large scale, once enabled as a virtual network function (VNF).

Traditional security approaches in OpenStack, such as security groups and FWaaS, lack flexibility and manageability. These solutions also do not provide sophisticated active responses like running defensive scripts in case of attacks, and are not effective in protecting big enterprise clouds against sophisticated cyber attacks.

A network IPS delivered through Tap-as-a-Service and vRouter (enabled by the Fuel Contrail plugin) as a forwarding plane can identify targeted attacks by monitoring and analyzing east-west traffic.

Moreover, we extend the architecture with an open source malware sandbox (e.g. Cuckoo or PyBox) as an IPS back end to identify targeted attacks (e.g. CloudAtlas and Minidionis APTs), and help an incident response team with a forensic investigation.

We will demonstrate features and discuss security best practices.
schedule.problem_addressed: Traditional security approaches implemented in OpenStack, such as security groups and FWaaS lack flexibility and manageability. These solutions do not provide active responses; like running defensive scripts or other sophisticated behavior in case of attacks. Thus, they are not effective in protecting big enterprise clouds against sophisticated cyber attacks.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn how to:

  • Use the Fuel Contrail plugin to enable SDN on top of OpenStack
  • Enable IPS as a VNF in OpenStack
  • Extend your security protection by enabling a malware sandbox
  • Detect targeted attacks with IPS and a malware sandbox

links.link: Dan Lambright, at OpenStack Summit 2015 in Vancouver, “Unobtrusive Intrusion Detection in Openstack”, link http://sched.co/2qji, video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xEmTDKqGEYs
Dan Lambright, at BDF 2015, "Intrusion Detection in the Cloud", video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H0RW_2CdM1k

Alexander Adamov, OpenStack Summit 2015 in Vancouver, “Detecting Targeted Attacks in the Cloud”, http://sched.co/2qi9, blog https://www.mirantis.com/blog/detecting-targeted-cyber-attacks-cloud/, video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_LGZ-evm-wQ

Alexander Adamov, Virus Bulletin 2015 in Prague, “Android ransomware: turning CryptoLocker into CryptoUnlocker (live demo)”, link https://www.virusbtn.com/conference/vb2015/abstracts/Adamov.xml, blog http://nioguard.blogspot.com/2015/09/teslacrypt-21-analysis-cracking-ping.html, video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kS7Z_Ap1wMQ

videos.name: Using Open Source Security Architecture to Defend against Targeted Attacks

schedule.title: Making the Economics of OpenStack Work
schedule.description: For OpenStack to become the way to organisations to deploy, manage and scale applications in the next decade, the economics need to stack up. How do the economics of OpenStack compare to existing virtualisation solutions or using public cloud platforms? As organisations look at the ever increasing options for workload and service delivery, this talk examines the costs of OpenStack today, how it measures up against the alternatives and what OpenStack users can do to improve the economics of running applications.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack is seen as a complex, premium infrastructure platform that requires expensive premium staff to run it. Some alternate application delivery platforms platforms are seen as simple and commodity. If these perceptions are real then OpenStack will have a tough time winning the lionshare of organisations over.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn about the complexity and cost challenges of OpenStack and how they compare to alternate application deployment platforms. Steps that can be taken to reduce OpenStack costs will also be covered.

videos.name: Making the Economics of OpenStack Work

schedule.title: Windows and OpenStack -  What's New in Windows Server 2016
schedule.description:
OpenStack is getting big in the enterprise, which is traditionally very Microsoft centeric. This session will show you everything you need to know about Windows in OpenStack!To begin with we will show how to provision Windows images for OpenStack, including Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows 7, 8.1 and the brand new Windows Server 2016 Nano Server for KVM, Hyper-V and ESXi Nova hosts.

Next, we will show how to deploy Windows workloads with Active Directory, SQL Server, SharePoint, Exchange using Heat templates, Juju, Puppet and more.

Last but not least, we'll talk about Active Directory integration in Keystone, Hyper-V deployment and Windows bare metal support in Ironic and MaaS. The session will give you a comprehensive view on how well OpenStack and Windows can be integrated, along with a great interoperability story with Linux workloads.
schedule.problem_addressed: There's a growing interest towards Windows in OpenStack and this session offers a clear overview of what is new in the Windows world from an OpenStack angle.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: With the upcoming release of Windows Server 2016, this session will guide the attendees through all the major new cloud features relevant for OpenStack.

videos.name: Windows and OpenStack -  What's New in Windows Server 2016

schedule.title: The Great Distro Bakeoff - Our Journey in Setting Up an OpenStack Environment that Actually Works
schedule.description: So you want a private OpenStack cloud? Think you can just grab your OpenStack distro of choice and get going? Well think again - nothing good comes that easy.  It’s not just about downloading some files and installing. There's a whole world of knowledge involved with doing this right, including how to configure, how to install, and most importantly how to maintain an administer your cloud. This is also one of the areas where the OpenStack ecosystem has moved way beyond what the vanilla OpenStack code provides.  Some of the important considerations when choosing an OpenStack distro are the support, maintenance, and management provided by the vendor, therefore, you will need to weigh the choices wisely.
schedule.problem_addressed: After two long years and four different distros, we’ll describe our own journey through the OpenStack distro selection process, the different challenges encountered, what influenced our choice of why we eventually chose the distro we are using, and where we expect to go next with building our private cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn the ins and outs of the various OpenStack distros and what to consider when choosing a distro.

videos.name: The Great Distro Bakeoff - Our Journey in Setting Up an OpenStack Environment that Actually Works

schedule.title: Hey Storage Engineer: Tell me About Backups in OpenStack!
schedule.description: With OpenStack rolling-out in high profile enterprises, data protection now becomes an important requirement throughout an application's lifecycle. This session will cover a variety of backup and restore options available for your OpenStack block and file storage. We will consider the various technologies for backups within local storage, to on-premise Swift, and offsite to public clouds. Come to learn about a comparison of  the different options and to discuss the strategy, architecture, configuration, and best practices of backup within an OpenStack environment.
schedule.problem_addressed: Keeping backups of your data can provide an added level of assurance in the event that your original data is lost due to disasters, human errors, data corruption, or other unforeseen factors. We will discuss the technologies and methodologies available for doing backups and restores in OpenStack environments.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: A variety of approaches to backing-up Cinder volumes and Manila shares within local storage, to on-site Swift and offsite public clouds.

videos.name: Hey Storage Engineer: Tell me About Backups in OpenStack!

schedule.title: Diamanti – How to Guarantee Performance for Containers at Scale
schedule.description:
Have you attempted to deploy Containerized apps at scale, and suffered the consequences? If you are spending months planning and building overprovisioned infrastructure to support your Containerized apps, come learn about modern infrastructure that is built for Containers.

Learn how to deploy Containers in minutes - at scale with guaranteed performance.

videos.name: Diamanti – How to Guarantee Performance for Containers at Scale

schedule.title: StackCity Austin: a Community Festival for Stackers - AT MAX CAPACITY
schedule.description:
UPDATE: The Party is now at MAX CAPACITY. 

 

Unfortunately the venue will not be able to accomodate any more people.

However, Austin has a lot to offer so check out our Local's Guide and enjoy your visit. 

RSVP REQUIRED

On Tuesday night, April 26, experience the best of what Austin has to offer at this Texas-sized community evening event. Stroll a few blocks from the Austin Convention Center and you’ll find an open-air party hosted at 15 bars and restaurants lining historic Rainey Street. Expect a few surprises in an evening offering something for everyone including live music from local artists, stand-up comedy, and, of course, barbecue and tacos.

Spotlight: SwiftStack
Startup: EasyStack, AeroFS, Bright Computing

schedule.title: The New Reality: Clusters, Containers and Thousands of Clouds
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Come join The New Stack for a short stack at the OpenStack pancake breakfast and podcast. Yes, it’s a pancake breakfast, but starring breakfast tacos! So wake up for the best hangover cure you can find and soak up the best conversation that can be had about the future of your infrastructure. Breakfast served at 7:30 am, discussion starts at 8:00 am.

schedule.title: Registration Check-In & Bag / Coat Check
EMC - Simplifying your setup and ongoing operations with a turnkey approach to building an OpenStack cloud
schedule.description: This session describes how easy it is to setup & operate a cloud using turnkey OpenStack based appliance starting from deployment, expansion, H/W replacement & monitoring. Increasingly organizations are turning to OpenStack to build their IT infrastructure. However, when trying to setup their own internal cloud using OpenStack, they face enormous challenges due to lack of skills, appropriate investments & underestimation of the complexity involved. This session talks about how customers can take advantage of a turnkey approach to deploying a cloud quickly. We will also describe how to expand, monitor & upgrade the cloud. Attendees will also get a glimpse of the kind of tradeoffs one has to make in developing a turnkey cloud.

videos.name: EMC - Simplifying your setup and ongoing operations with a turnkey approach to building an OpenStack cloud

schedule.title: Documentation: Work session
Fuel: Work session
Magnum: Work session
State Grid Corporation of China Embraces OpenStack to Avoid Vendor Lock-In
schedule.description: State Grid Corporation of China (SGCC) is the largest electric utility company in the world,  the seventh largest company in the world according to the 2011 Fortune Global 500 ranking. SGCC used to mainly  use commercial products in their IT systems, to reduce cost and avoid vendor lock-in, the open source technology has started to be adopted in SGCC recently. OpenStack is one of the practise they take to build self-controlled private cloud.
schedule.problem_addressed:
The session will cover the benefits SGCC get by using OpenStack, for example, flexibility it brings to the business. And also the challenges that traditional enterprises meet when adopting open source technologies, including different skills set, organizational adjustments, process changes, etc.

The details as below:

1. Scalable infrastructure better supports innovation workloads

2. Open source software with commodity hardware, reduced a good percent of IT spending

3. Migration of traditional workloads to OpenStack is no easy job

4. The automation of new operation proceeses is developed

5. Performance tuning of ceph using IB technology

6. How to fill in the skills gap for OpenStack operation
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: And also the challenges ahead not only technical issues need to be overcome but also orgnizational challenges.

schedule.title: Sahara: Work session
TryStack: The Free OpenStack Sandbox for Earth
schedule.description:
The OpenStack Foundation and several generous corporate sponsors (including Red Hat, Dell, Cisco, and NetApp) setup and operate TryStack.org - a free way to try out and learn more about OpenStack and it's capabilities in a large, public sandbox.

TryStack is a production OpenStack implementation and the maintainers have learned a great deal about deployments, maintenance, automation, monitoring, upgrades and gotchas.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this talk, several members of the TryStack team will:·

 

  • Talk about the history of TryStack and future roadmap

  • Give insight into deployment architecture and underlying components·

  • Illustrate the various capabilities of TryStack

  • Explain how TryStack is evolving with OpenStack

  • Upstream Manila development happening on Trystack

schedule.title: Monasca: Work session
OpenStackAnsible: Work session
RefStack: Work session

Winstackers: Work session
Ironic: Nova-compatible VNC console
Senlin: Work session
Swift: Community Feedback and How to Contribute
Kolla: Adding a Kubernetes Underlay
Project Kuryr - Docker Delivered, Kubernetes Next!
schedule.description:
Kuryr was unveiled in the OpenStack Summit in Tokyo.

Its goal is to make Neutron networking available to containainers in their most widespread usages.

Kuryr's aim, as we move towards the N release, is to bridge the gap between the container orchestration engines like Kubernetes and OpenStack networking models and expose all of the production grade Neutron capabilities and services to big scale container consumers.

In this session we will talk about how Kuryr bridged the gap with Docker standalone configurations, how it brings networking to Docker Swarm and what is the roadmap for the next release.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Project Kuryr aims at helping containers deployments and mixed containers OpenStack deployments to leverage OpenStack networking solutions and abstraction (Neutron) for containers networking and work together with common containers orchestration engines like Docker Swarm, Kubernetes, Mesos.

By Levering Kuryr the user can have seamless integration with any Neutron solution out there, Any Neutron implementation can now be used as a containers networking solution but still use the same API and orchestration methods the user is used too.

Kuryr is able to expose additional features implemented by Neutron and advance network services (LBaaS, FWaaS and more) and enable the user/deployer from using them in their containers networking just as well.

Kuryr is tackling the use case of running nested containers in a tenant VM and tries to simplify such enviorments by exposing Neutron plugins/solution that support such use cases, this can later be used by project Magnum.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees should get a short introduction to project Kuryr, the problems its trying to solve and the solutions its offer.

They will learn the features implemented in Mitaka and Liberty, like:

  • Full integration with Docker and Docker Swarm
  • Support for Docker pluggable IPAM
  • Fullstack / CI / Benchmarking tests in the gate
  • Generic VIF Binding
  • Packaging

They will also hear about the design and implementation of Kubernetes integration and plans to support Magnum and integrate with it. in addition to our roadmap for the next release.

videos.name: Project Kuryr - Docker Delivered, Kubernetes Next!

schedule.title: Infrastructure: Community Task-Tracking
Telco Cloud Requirements: What VNF's Are Asking For
schedule.description:
This talk will focus on the evolving requirements of current and future Telco Cloud deployments.

Network Functions are widely deployed today with quantified performance, failure and capacity requirements. As those functions make their way to a Telco Cloud, it is clear that various characteristics are required of the Cloud to preserve the brown field migration of these functions.

Requirements of Telco Cloud deployments range from high availability and liveness detection of network connectivity (PING, BFD, TCP Socket Level Checks, etc.), preserving existing network reachability with protocols such as BGP, marking tenant workload packets with correct QOS values, high I/O performance characteristics with SR-IOV/DPDK, etc.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: The use case and problems being discussed are specific to existing and future VNF's and how the migration efforts are driving specific requirements of the Telco Cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will understand evolving VNF's requirements of the Telco Cloud from real world deployments and how these requirements are being addressed.

videos.name: Telco Cloud Requirements: What VNF's Are Asking For

schedule.title: Designate: Talk to the Devs
Continuously Delivering OpenStack Using OpenStack-Salt
schedule.description:
From the moment OpenStack control plane is deployed it becomes a working piece of history. Why not treat OpenStack services like set of living projects that uses the same tools the developers use to build, test and deploy your OpenStack? Openstack-salt provides model that allows to deploy security patches, bug fixes, manage service lifecycle and releases off a simple git commit. This makes your OpenStack operationally manageable once again and adding new hypervisors or entire regions is fun again. Continuous Delivery with Openstack-salt doesn't mean that every change is deployed to production right away, but means that every changes is proven and can be deployed safely at any time.

What is the problem or use case you’re addressing in this session?

How do you stay current with OpenStack? How to control operations of your OpenStack deployment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How to make OpenStack operationally manageable with specific examples of how we continuously deliver OpenStack using Openstack-salt model-based pipelines. 

 

Why should this session be selected? Our session tackles real world problems that large scale companies are going to face when operating OpenStack.

schedule.description:

Proactively ensuring your OpenStack cloud is performing optimally and in accordance with relevant industry compliance requirements can be a confusing and time consuming process. This two hour hands-on course will provide participants with a foundation in OpenStack monitoring and compliance. Specifically, we will explore:

OpenStack Monitoring Landscape

Logs and Events

  • Log interpretation

Compliance 

  • Common compliance requirements by industry
  • Key resources for compliance

Implement a monitoring solution

  • Install Goldstone

  • Hands on lab

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

TRAINING INFO:

Install, configure, and maintain an OpenStack computing environment using Fuel The OpenStack Fuel Administration (FUEL100) course is a two day course that exposes participants to the required knowledge to understand and effectively leverage Mirantis' OpenStack distribution. Unlike our other OpenStack course offerings, the FUEL100 course focuses on the Mirantis OpenStack projects: Fuel, Murano, and Sahara. schedule.title: Neutron DSCP: Policing your Network
schedule.description: DSCP is used by large enterprises to manage network traffic intelligently. It provides quality of service to enable traffic engineering, and in some cases can additionally be relied on to enforce network security policies. The inclusion of DSCP in Newton Neutron now makes this facility available to all users, from individuals to large enterprises. This talk will describe DSCP for those unfamiliar with it, discuss how DSCP is used ‘in the wild’ today, and relate the path taken to deliver the Open vSwitch-based reference implementation for Newton.
schedule.problem_addressed:
The following are use cases for DSCP that will be discussed during this presentation:

  • An Openstack cloud provider wants to segregate traffic between different kinds of virtual hosts based on a designation other than their tenant/project.
  • An Openstack cloud provider has some traffic that must always, always get through, even during times of traffic congestion, and needs to prioritize that traffic over other traffic accordingly.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees should expect to learn:

  • A basic overview defining DSCP, how it is implemented in the TCP header, and how network devices react to it;
  • An overview of a few real-world use cases for DSCP, taken from several large enterprises, to show what problems it is used to solve as well as what problems it is not well-suited for;
  • How the reference implementation for DSCP control is implemented in Neutron using Open vSwitch, and what issues needed to be addressed for that to happen.

videos.name: Neutron DSCP: Policing your Network

schedule.title: Mesos and OpenStack: The Perfect Tag Team for Containers
schedule.description:
Container Orchestration Engines such as Kubernetes and Swarm provide full management for containers, however they assume that the cluster infrastructure is provided by someone else. OpenStack provides the full infrastructure and Magnum integrates these resources for the Container Orchestration Engine, but the resource management is left to the users. Mesos on the other hand provides advanced, highly scalable resource management.

Recent development allows Kubernetes and Swarm to run on Mesos as frameworks. This makes it now possible to bring the 3 layers together to achieve a new level of integration and automation, yielding many benefits: scaling at both the container and the node level, fine grained resource sharing among clusters, etc.

In this talk, we will take a close look at running Kubernetes and Swarm workloads on Mesos, hosted on OpenStack. We will show the necessary plumbing for the integration, and discuss potential issues in providing networking and storage through Mesos.
schedule.problem_addressed:
A production environment to support containers faces several challenges.

With the choices in Container Orchestration Engines, workloads inevitably will be implemented in both Kubernetes and Swarm, not just one or the other.  They will need to work together seamlessly.  Resources will need to be shared fairly and dynamically between Kubernetes and Swarm clusters.  Resource management needs to be automated.

While no single solution exists that will address all these challenges, current projects do offer complementary features that together, may provide the necessary support.  In particular, we will look into solving these problems by using Mesos on OpenStack as the platform to host Kubernetes and Swarm workloads.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The audience will gain an understanding on how well Mesos and OpenStack complement each other to host disparate container workloads. 

We will identify best practices as well as gaps that may drive new development in the respective communities.

videos.name: Mesos and OpenStack: The Perfect Tag Team for Containers

schedule.title: Deploying OpenStack-Ansible - The Quick and Dirty Guide
schedule.description:
Deploying OpenStack is hard, deploying OpenStack with the openstack-ansible project is less hard... We would like to show you how you can make it even easier and address some of the problems and questions that we get regarding deploying OpenStack using openstack-ansible.

This will include:

  • A general 'how to' starting from initial basic setup, to expanding your deployment.
  • How, and where to make configuration changes.
  • What to do when openstack-ansible does not support your customization.
  • Tips and tricks to help you with openstack-ansible.
  • How to build on your openstack-ansible deployment with custom components.
  • Where to go for help.
schedule.problem_addressed: While openstack-ansible is a great way to get around the difficulties of deploying OpenStack, getting to grips with it can be a bit daunting at first.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: What is required for, and how to configure, an openstack-ansible deployment. Where, and how, to configure and customize your deployment. Tips and tricks to help make the process easier. How to expand your deployment and add custom elements, as well as where you can go to get help.

videos.name: Deploying OpenStack-Ansible - The Quick and Dirty Guide

schedule.title: Stateless Hypervisors at Scale, We'll Do It Live!
schedule.description: In this presentation we will introduce a method of booting Nova hypervisors over the network into a stateless live booted operating system. By using a live operating system, we separate the stateless operating system running in RAM from the Nova configuration and instance data which is persistent on disk. Because the OS is an image, it's easier to jump across versions as you can load the latest version of the OS by either doing a reboot or a kexec. It also helps maintain consistency and ensures that whenever a machine goes down for maintenance or a reboot, it will come back on the latest and greatest build. We'll touch on how the OS can be maintained using Git and how CI/CD can be utilized to automatically generate the latest version of the build and deploy it.
schedule.problem_addressed: Hypervisors become inconsistent over time from maintenances, code releases, and manual troubleshooting. Optimizations, patches, and security fixes are pushed with new deployments but older deployments in production never get caught up. Without a solid plan of attack, things can spiral out of control quickly. This presentation will present potential methods to avoid the situations above.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• What is a live OS and what is it useful for?
  • How to build a live bootable, stateless, version controlled server image using Jenkins and Ansible
  • How to deliver live images over the networks using Torrents for distribution
  • How to provision a reproducible environment for developers and quality engineers

videos.name: Stateless Hypervisors at Scale, We'll Do It Live!

schedule.title: Deploying OpenStack for The National Science Foundation's Newest Supercomputers
schedule.description: The National Science Foundation has recently funded two high performance computing resources powered by OpenStack.  The Bridges machine at Pittsburgh Super Computing Center and Jetstream at Indiana University/Texas Advanced Computing Center comprise a combined $16.2 million dollar investment in 18 petabytes of storage, 40864 processor cores,and  354 terabytes of memory.  The architecture, performance, use cases, and deployment details of each of these two machines will be covered.
schedule.problem_addressed: Deploying openstack to service high performance computing workflows.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn architecture and deployment details, use cases, and benchmarks results for two National Science Foundation computational resources. Jetstream http://jetstream-cloud.org and Bridges https://www.psc.edu/bridges

videos.name: Deploying OpenStack for The National Science Foundation's Newest Supercomputers

schedule.title: Distributed NFV & OpenStack: Challenges and Potential Solutions
schedule.description:
Review and proposed next steps for challenges BT found with OpenStack for Distributed NFV use cases. At SDN World Congress last year, Peter Willis of British Telecom presented a set of challenges that are preventing BT from using OpenStack for Distributed NFV deployments – specifically for virtual CPE or vBranch use case. 

This session will explore more about the challenges and attempts to identify near-term and long-term solutions. The solutions will range from creative ways of leveraging Linux capabilities, selective use of OpenStack, and other open source projects like OpenDayLight in the short term and identify promising OpenStack blueprints and projects for longer-term solutions.

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Distributed NFV imposes a different set of deployment challenges on OpenStack especially when applied to virtual CPE use case where the edge devices are spread over 1000’s (or more) of distributed sites. 

  1. Binding Virtual Network Interface Cards to the Virtual Network Function 
  2. Service chain modification 
  3. Scalability of the controller(s) 
  4. Start-up Storms (Or Stampedes) 
  5. Securing OpenStack over the Internet 
  6. Backwards compatibility between releases
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This session will be delivered as a talk that provides details for each of top six challenges followed by a set of potential solutions - both short and longer term solutions for each. The attendees will gain an understanding of

  • Requirements for the virtual CPE use case
  • Top six challenges or inhibitors to using OpenStack at the network edge
  • Possible short term solutions for each of these challenges
  • Promising blueprints & proposals for addressing these in the longer term

videos.name: Distributed NFV & OpenStack: Challenges and Potential Solutions

schedule.title: Openstack Components as Containerized MicroServices
schedule.description:
Openstack is already an ecosystem designed with microservices in mind. Now its time to start using it is designed. By deploying openstack components with a microservice architecture in mind it will allow you to scale, recover from disasters, redeploy and upgrade with ease.

Containerizing this micro services will provide you an easy way to test and even deploy from the latest and greatest code from community, allowing you to test many new features before you need to roll them out to you production cloud.
schedule.problem_addressed: Showing how openstack components can scale individually providing an easy way to manage and deploy new updates to each of them by reducing the complexity of the overall maintenance and software development life cycle using containers and microservices.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
By attending this session users should expect to learn:

  • What is required to containerize the core components of openstack.
  • Creating containers from stable and master.
  • Architecting components as microservices.
  • Which components are not designed for containers.
  • Tools required in order to achieve and orchestrate microservices and containers.
  • Workflow to upgrade.

videos.name: Openstack Components as Containerized MicroServices

schedule.title: Zaqar Messaging for Microservices and IoT
schedule.description: One of the challenges that users face when developing an application using a microservices architecture is how to distribute information between each microservice. Similar challenges can be seen in IoT and sensor applications - how can you efficiently receive data from huge numbers of devices? For the purpose of our presentation we developed a demo on resolving these communication and distribution problems using Zaqar, OpenStack’s Messaging and Notification service.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Communicating between microservices, devices and application users is a huge problem when developing applications to run on OpenStack. This session will introduce Zaqar for the following uses:

  • Distributing tasks among workers
  • Notifying end-users in their browser when a task they care about is completed
  • Coordinating cluster-wide actions (like pausing jobs) across all workers
  • Receiving sensor-type time series data and ingesting to a datastore

This will be targeted to developers of applications on OpenStack that are trying to build more "cloud-native" services that are loosely coupled but require coordination. Zaqar provides messaging primitives that make building these types of apps simpler, and handles scaling and durability without user intervention. For IoT developers, the wide support for sending data to HTTP APIs is critical for the wide variety of device OS?. Zaqar also supports websockets to let clients receive messages in-browser without polling.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: From this presentation/demo, attendees will learn how to leverage OpenStack Zaqar to develop a cloud-based/distributed microservice architecture. The demo will include a full application that uses Zaqar for user notifications and work queueing.

videos.name: Zaqar Messaging for Microservices and IoT

schedule.title: Swift Object Encryption
schedule.description:
A new feature in development for OpenStack Swift improves security by encrypting object data at rest.

OpenStack Swift provides reliable and scalable object storage that has been deployed in many successful production environments. The Swift developer community has recently been working on enhancing Swift’s security by adding the capability to encrypt object content stored on disk. Our goal is to protect data at rest from an attacker that gains physical access to disks. We aim to achieve this with complete transparency to clients i.e. with no API changes, other than optional extensions to support client provided keys when desired.

This talk will describe and demonstrate this exciting new feature, discuss options for integration with key management services such as Barbican, and look ahead at future work to additionally encrypt account and container metadata.
schedule.problem_addressed:
We’re addressing the security of data at rest in Swift clusters. Users’ data is at risk of exposure should a third party gain access to a disk. Disks could be stolen, mistakenly disposed of before being scrubbed, or faulty and therefore unable to be scrubbed.

Users can of course guard against this risk by encrypting data before sending to Swift, but often a server-side encryption service is desirable. This may be because operators themselves must ensure encryption of data at rest to satisfy regulatory and/or customer requirements, or because clients do not wish to manage encryption keys.

Our solution encrypts objects as they arrive at a Swift proxy. This has advantages over other server-side encryption approaches: encrypting content once in the proxy incurs lower CPU overhead than having each replica encrypted on object servers using existing block encryption tools such as dm-crypt; encrypting in Swift itself avoids the cost of upgrading hardware to self-encrypting disks.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn about the goals (and non-goals) of Swift encryption, hear about the progress being made towards encryption being enabled in upstream Swift, see a demonstration of object encryption and gain an understanding of the trade-offs with other encryption solutions.

links.link: Feature branch in Swift repo at https://github.com/openstack/swift/tree/feature/crypto

videos.name: Swift Object Encryption

schedule.title: Getting Started With OpenStack
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

OpenStack continues to grow as the de facto standard for open source Cloud platforms and private clouds in general. But how can someone quickly get started with learning this technology? This workshop will walk participants through an overview of the most deployed OpenStack components and offer practical suggestions and resources for learning OpenStack.

As part of this workshop, we will assist attendees with deploying a test OpenStack instance on their laptops using Vagrant, VirtualBox, and RDO. The relevant Vagrant file and pre-workshop instructions will be included in the final abstract if this workshop is approved. We will then walk attendees through the horizon dashboard and the OpenStack CLI to manage and use their new OpenStack instance.

----------------------------------------------------

Before you arrive at this session please complete the "Preparation" 
section of these instructions: 
https://radez.fedorapeople.org/GettingStartedWithOpenStack.html 


It will take some time and bandwidth, please plan accordingly.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack can be difficult to install for new users. Using Vagrant, VirtualBox, and RDO, we will show participants one option to get going on their laptops and give then a sandbox environment they can continue to use to learn post-Summit. By walking through various projects usng Horizon and the CLI, we hope to help participants get comfortable with OpenStack and to continue further learning.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees shoudl expect to learn the following:

  • A short history and overview of the OpenStack project
  • An understanding of the best use cases for an OpenStack cloud
  • An overview of the various components of OpenStack
  • How to deploy OpenStack
  • How to navigate the Horizon dashboard
  • How to use the CLI to manage OpenStack
  • Setting up tenants and users
  • Provisioning cloud resources such as VMs, netwoks, and block storage

videos.name: Getting Started With OpenStack

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: EMC - Accelerated cloud native application development
schedule.description: Getting an application development environment up and running on top of OpenStack can be challenging and time consuming. How to reduce time to code? How do you deploy and scale applications with ease? How do you leverage containers to develop micro services? Do you have to choose between structured & unstructured PaaS? How do you integrate your cloud-native platform into existing enterprise operational systems? We will show how EMC’s turn-key OpenStack powered appliance addresses these issues and enables you to start developing cloud native applications in a matter of hours.

schedule.description: Enterprises are increasingly adopting cloud to support digital transfomation. We will deep dive into cloud adoption strategies, maturity levels, specific, common use cases while taking a broad view of IT strategy, architecture, and organizational design. From collective discussion, we will build roadmap for a public, private and hybrid cloud journey leveraging best practices, common techniques, lessons learned and real-world examples from OpenStack adoptors.
schedule.problem_addressed:
During interactions with hundreds of customers we have found following important considerations and problems in the adoption of cloud:

1. What benefits will I get from cloud adoption?

2. Should I build public, private or hybrid cloud?

3. Do I have sufficient skills in the organization for successful cloud adoption?

4. ok, I am conviced about building private cloud. What are my next steps?

 

This is a high level cloud adoption disucssion which leverages lessons learned and best practices to arrive at prescriptive road map for building an 'optimized' cloud strategy.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn on how to build a successful cloud strategy and execution plan. We will discuss common use cases, and benefits that attendees can achive by adopting cloud. More importantly we will answer what are the considerations that successful adoptors prescribe.

Scality - Six Years OpenStack, What’s Next? Featuring Marc Shuttleworth (Canonical), Steve Muir (Comcast), Jerome Lecat (Scality), and Ashish Nadkarni (IDC)
schedule.description:
It was in the Austin Convention center that OpenStack was first announced in July 2010 by the Rackspace marketing team.

It was in the Austin Convention center that OpenStack was first announced in July 2010 by the Rackspace marketing team. The OpenStack project was started to help organizations build cloud-computing services leveraging standard hardware. The community's first official release appeared four months later. In 2011, developers of the Ubuntu Linux distribution adopted OpenStack. Ubuntu's sponsor Canonical then introduced full support for OpenStack clouds.\n\nIn the years to come, OpenStack would become the biggest open source initiative since Linux, supported by a fast-growing community. A recent major breakthrough came in August 2015, when Platform9 announced that its OpenStack distribution was fully interoperable with VMware vSphere.

Join us for - and participate in - an exciting panel with Canonical's Marc Shuttleworth, Scality's Jerome Lecat, Matthew Curley from HPE and Steve Muir from Comcast, moderated by Ashish Nadkarni from IDC. The panelists will give their views on the past and future of OpenStack: what have we achieved so far, where are we going and most importantly, how will users benefit from the community's efforts?

Project Vitrage: How to Organize, Analyze and Visualize your OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description:
When problems or strange behaviors emerge in a complex cloud environment, it's difficult to understand what is causing them, making the management of such systems untenable.

The Vitrage project is designed to address precisely this.

Vitrage is a new Root Cause Analysis Engine for organizing, analyzing and expanding OpenStack alarms & events, yielding insights regarding the root cause of problems and deducing the existence of problems before they are directly detected.

Its ultimate goal is that every significant occurrence in the cloud should have a timely alarm generated for it, and that the cause-effect relationships between these events is understood and visualized.

In this session we'll present Vitrage for the first time. In addition to going over its goals, design and planned features, we will demo three features supported for the Mitaka version of Vitrage:

1. A clear view of the Cloud Topology

2. Configurable template-based raising of alarms

3. The Root Cause Analysis of these alarms
schedule.problem_addressed:
The main problem Vitrage addresses, is the lack of a clear and unified view of what is happening in the Cloud.

We’ll explore this issue by demonstrating three major features of Vitrage. 

The first is a clear visualization of the cloud structure and state, based on the Nova and Ceilometer/Aodh projects, and on the Nagios system – the first Vitrage plugins implemented for Mitaka. The Vitrage Topology API with it's own interactive UI, allows the user to see the different resources and what they are connected to. 

The second is the ability within Vitrage, to create an alarm on a resource, for a problem that was "deduced" to have occurred based on a set of existing alarms. This expands the range of alarms that can be raised, giving the user a clearer and more complete sense of the state of the Cloud. 

And finally, Root Cause Analysis. We’ll demonstrate the new horizon plugin for Vitrage, which allows retrieving and visualizing RCA information in an intuitive and interactive graphical manner.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees of this session will learn how Vitrage can help them improve their understanding of their OpenStack environment.

Whether an IT manager or an application owner on the cloud, Vitrage can help them get a clear idea of what is happening, and get to the root of the problem quickly. 

OpenStack developers will benefit further from this session.

Vitrage has a pluggable architecture, with the ability to integrate new information sources easily as well as define new types of alarms to raise.

Developers will discover how they can help move Vitrage forward to reach its maximum potential, whether for their own company or for the OpenStack community. 

Furthermore, as this is the first time Vitrage is presented, attendees will get to hear about the motivation behind the project, its core design principles, and its current status

videos.name: Project Vitrage: How to Organize, Analyze and Visualize your OpenStack Cloud

schedule.title: Telemetry: Work session
NetApp - I want it now!  Or, doing more with less for accelerating application development for Developers.
schedule.description: TBA
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
More often then not code development takes more time and resources than planned for.  Developers lose time waiting for code to compile in their respective workspaces, hoping they asked for just enough resources, but not so much as to break-the-bank.  Yet, if they underestimate then they will loose even more time.  

Through the use of simple templates, scripts and API’s, near instantaneous workspace creation can be put in the hands of developers, no matter where they are doing the work.  This session will show you how using some simple tricks and tools that take advantage of a combination features including snapshots and clones.  Developers can now create workspace in seconds without taking up additional resources thereby reducing the build time.

Key Takeaways

1) Instantaneous user workspace creation to improve developer’s productivity.

2) Provide faster build cycles with a high degree of storage space efficiency

3) Provision on demand compute resources in a hybrid cloud model for builds that have bursts of workloads.

 

Why this session should be selected

Optimizing underlying infrastructure can accelerate the build cycles for the developers.

videos.name: NetApp - I want it now!  Or, doing more with less for accelerating application development for Developers.

schedule.title: Oculus for OpenStack Ops (OpenStack Goes 3D)
schedule.description:
OpenStack Horizon, command-line clients and API libraries let developers and operators interact directly, indirectly, and automatically with a target cloud. Analytics tools like Stacklight (LMA toolchain) give deeper insight with sophisticated interactive graphics and out-of-band interaction channels like Nagios alerts. Beyond these tools, however, lies a new world of VR-based immersive UX for operations, visualization and collaboration.

In this session, we’ll discuss:

  • Open-source toolchain options for building immersive UX around cloud computing
  • UI widgets, DevOps and dataviz metaphors (from skeuomorphism to … beyond!)
  • The Internet of Things (to Visualize): VR + OpenStack + IoT = Value
  • How to build your own Minority Report-style UI (with no Tom Cruise in it)

And demonstrate a virtual-reality collaborative OpenStack operations environment compatible with Oculus Rift.
schedule.problem_addressed: Operators, developers and users need to be able to better visualize and more-fluently interact with data, with clouds, and with one another. Open source VR technology enables rapid creation and customization of sophisticated immersive multi-user work, learning and demo environments to enable more effective (and awesome, let’s face it) operations and group productivity.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about:

  • Open-source toolchain options for building immersive UX around cloud computing
  • UI widgets, DevOps and dataviz metaphors (from skeuomorphism to … beyond!)
  • The Internet of Things (to Visualize): VR + OpenStack + IoT = Value
  • How to build your own Minority Report-style UI (with no Tom Cruise in it)

And they'll see demonstrated a virtual-reality collaborative OpenStack operations environment compatible with Oculus Rift.

videos.name: Oculus for OpenStack Ops (OpenStack Goes 3D)

schedule.title: OpenStack at Scale inside NetApp: Trials and Tribulations
schedule.description:
Want to hear from how we've implemented OpenStack internally inside our engineering support organization?  How we're able to scale to over 7000 VM instances, 14,000 cores across 3 geographical regions (2 US, 1 India)?  Also how we're able to automate upgrades with Puppet between releases for a non-disruptive experience for our users?   If so, this session is for you! 

We will focus on a couple of key findings:

What influence the needs of our users had on the choice of the underlying compute, storage and networking layer

What challenges we faced when combining this new self-service environment with best practices of traditional IT and virtualization, with a focus on automation and ease-of-use for both our developers and our operators

How OpenStack challenges the status quo of support organizations, and where we are taking our internal deployment next

Tips for selecting and sourcing optimal hardware for OpenStack deployments, with reference architecture advice on optimal deployments
schedule.problem_addressed:
This session is targeted towards enterprise IT architects wanting to hear how NetApp, a Fortune 500 IT company and the largest independent storage provider architected and delivered OpenStack internally.

At NetApp, we provide a production engineering environment to thousands of users who rely on it for their day-to-day tasks.  As such, we strive to maintain the right balance of introducing new features, new hardware solutions,reference architectures, etc. vs. the need to provide a highly reliable environment for our engineers. 

Our OpenStack environment provides real-world coverage and runtime of the drivers that NetApp pushes to upstream OpenStack release, specifically in the Cinder and Manila areas.  Additionally, by deploying OpenStack, Netapp is able to provide a reliable and scalable environment that allows engineers to get to get the storage, network and virtual machines instances they need in an on-demand, self-service environment that is always on.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will hear real-world experiences of OpenStack deployments in the enterprise.  Not only will strategies for success be discussed, but also trials/tribulations and potential pitfalls and learnings so that other folks will not make the same mistakes.  Also the role of converged infrastructure in an OpenStack deployment and the scalability of the infrastructure will be stressed, with a concentration on how a traditional engineering support organization historically providing VMWare hosting tackles OpenStack operations and developer support as an internal function.

videos.name: OpenStack at Scale inside NetApp: Trials and Tribulations

schedule.title: High-Performance OpenStack for Science and Data Analytics in a Hybrid Cloud Environment
schedule.description: Traditionally, high-performance science and data analytics workloads have been run on specialized clusters tailored to a small number of applications.  OpenStack provides a superior cloud platform that not only accommodates a wider range of applications than specialized clusters but also reduces costs by running steady state workloads on-premise while providing the ability to “burst” into a variety of off-premise clouds.  This session details technology and architectures to optimize OpenStack for technical and data-intensive computing as well as techniques for tailoring HPC workloads for better portability and performance on private and public cloud platforms.  Lastly, we cover case studies that demonstrate how research organizations leverage OpenStack to address these issues in pursuit of their life-changing missions.
schedule.problem_addressed: Unless architected properly, OpenStack is only applicable to a narrow set of HPC workloads.  This talk conveys architectures and techniques to allow the use of OpenStack for a wider range of applications.  It also details ways in which HPC workloads can be tailored for better portability and performance on cloud platforms such as OpenStack.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
- Topologies for both high-speed/low-latency communication among instances and high-throughput transfers between instances and shared storage.

- Enabling a “Science DMZ” for high-throughput, wide-area data transfers.

- The use of IPv6 for instance communication and how it addresses certain limitations.

- The use of Ironic to support containers, special hardware, and bare metal workloads.

- Using resource schedulers such as Slurm and Mesos to enable meta-scheduling between specialized clusters, on-premise OpenStack cloud, and off-premise clouds.

- Hybrid computing between private and public clouds (e.g. AWS).

- Techniques and technologies for providing scale-out file, block, and object storage.

- Techniques for tailoring HPC workloads for maximum portability and performance on cloud platforms such as OpenStack

videos.name: High-Performance OpenStack for Science and Data Analytics in a Hybrid Cloud Environment

schedule.title: Service Function Chaining – Technology Analysis and Perspective
schedule.description:
Service chaining plays an important role in network function virtualization by stitching together an ordered list of virtual network functions, such as routers, firewalls, load balancers etc., to achieve a particular complex service that previously required multiple physical appliances. This presentation will review and analyze two major technologies that enable service function chaining, i.e. NSH-based SFC and BGPVPN-based SFC, followed by current status of various projects addressing SFC, MPLS / BGP VPN, and related APIs in OPNFV, OpenStack and Open Daylight. Lastly, this presentation will also review a prior PoC that implemented inter-DC SFC using BGPVPN technology.

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: There are two major technologies in enabling service function chaining for network function virtualization, i.e. NSH-based SFC and BGPVPN-based SFC. Both technologies address SFC in different ways with their own pros and cons. It is always a challenge for an end user, especially network operators and service providers, to choose which technology should be chosen in real world deployment. This presentation will review both technologies, their pros and cons, and implications in deployment from an end user perspective, and review a prior PoC that implemented inter-DC SFC using BGPVPN technology.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The audience is anyone who is interested in SFC technologies. Attendees can expect a detailed review of technology analysis of both BGPVPN and NSH that can enable SFC use cases. Attendees can also expect a landscaping of SFC / BGPVPN / NSH related projects in open source communities such as OPNFV, OpenStack and Open Daylight. In addition, attendees can also benefit from the introduction of a PoC that implemented inter-DC SFC using BGPVPN technology, and expectation from an end user perspective.

videos.name: Service Function Chaining – Technology Analysis and Perspective

schedule.title: Among the Cloud: Open Source NFV + SDN deployment
schedule.description:
Panel discussion

Moderator: Neela Jacques

Panelists: Chris Price (OPNFV); Colin Dixon (ODL); Margaret Chiosi (AT&T); Alex Zhang (China Mobile)

Seven years after the launch of SDN and the development of OpenFlow, SDN and NFV are changing the networking landscape. NFV is quickly going from white paper to POC to deployment and a dominant stack is emerging. Dozens of new products are being released based on open innovation and cloud-based deployments are on the rise. Hear  industry experts discuss the latest new SDN and NFV use cases, how SDN and NFV impact cloud deployments, the evolution of the end user and what’s on the horizon.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session investigates questions of how SDN and NFV have evolved, what sorts of use cases are being implemented and what's on the horizon. Experts from two open source networking projects --OpenDaylight and OPNFV --will provide insight in conjunction with two end users -Comcast and AT&T --that are both leveraging open source networking to actualize SDN and NFV.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how end users collaborate with open source netowrking projects to actualize SDN and NFV and how the community --vendors, end users, service providers --works together towards a common goal of transforming the networking industry.

videos.name: Among the Cloud: Open Source NFV + SDN deployment

schedule.title: Building Real-Time Cloud Using OpenStack
schedule.description: Users or operators sometimes need to run low-latency or real-time applications (such as audio/video streaming, highly interactive systems, etc.) to meet their requirements in clouds,  and in fact it seems that it is one of the reasons why people need to use Ironic on OpenStack, although Ironic lacks management advantage of virtualization. And a good news is that we have sufficient infrastructure to achieve that in OpenStack (in the M release). With these features, OpenStack can host low-latency or real-time applications without using Ironic. However, it’s still cumbersome to configure and build such real-time clouds.Since we are working on Real-time KVM as one of the projects of KVM enhancements for NFV at OPNFV, we share our know-how and experiences to build real-time clouds using OpenStack.In this session, we will show how to configure Nova nodes (CPU, I/O, memory, etc.) and root-cause potential problems with real-time applications on OpenStack.
schedule.problem_addressed: We have sufficient infrastructure or parts to run low-latency or real-time applications in OpenStack clouds, but it is still difficult to build such clouds because one needs to understand the deep vertical software layers, from the hypervisor to the orchestration layer.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Whoever interested in running low-latency or real-time applications (such as audio/video streaming, highly interactive systems, etc.) in OpenStack clouds. Also, this type of cloud should meet the requirements of HPC. Also, whoever wants to stop using Ironic (but cannot because of low-latency or real-time requirements).

videos.name: Building Real-Time Cloud Using OpenStack

schedule.title: OpenStack Operation Under a Multi-Tenant and Multi-Customer Public Cloud Environment
schedule.description: We at NTT Communications have recently launched the public/hosted private cloud service "Enterprise Cloud 2.0" with OpenStack Juno. Since the main target users are Enterprise users, there were some gaps between the OpenStack community version and what the user wants. To fill in the gaps (e.g. VM is required more reliability, connection with multiple NW gw's needs to be automated), we have designed an architecture with Virtual Machine High Availability (VM-HA) function, specialized virtualized network (ESI, Elastic Service Infrastructure), and developed operation tools, which can scale out the number of cases our operation engineers can handle. We will share the operation design and knowledge to operate OpenStack under this kind of environment, which is multi-tenant and multi-customer. We will also share the shift in thinking from our experience of having operated another Cloud management platform.
schedule.problem_addressed:
• Migration from Legacy systems (without Cloud native Application Architecture) are big challenges for customers
  • In multi-tenant/multi-customer environment, many customer VMs reside in one host. When an system failure occurs, It is difficult to find out which customer needs to be notified
  • There is difficulty in tracking VM information, such as VM location history, when using VM-HA during Nova compute node down incidents, during which VM-HA immediately moves VMs to other nodes
  • During network system failure, there is difficulty in tracking affected virtualized networks from physical network-virtualized network relationship
  • To handle multiple issues in same timing, a lot of man power is needed in widespread system failure/customer inquiry handling (e.g. recovery process/health check automation)
  • Resource problems experienced by the customer are sometimes not detected from the system side (e.g. compute node monitoring, and other OpenStack services and infrastructures)
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
- The requirements for an Enterprise public cloud service 
- How OpenStack is integrated into NTT Communications Enterprise Cloud 
- How Masakari, the VM-HA function in OpenStack, operates 
- Experience and challenges of operating a multi-tenant and multi-customer environment with large number of virtual resources 
- And how these challenges were solved

videos.name: OpenStack Operation Under a Multi-Tenant and Multi-Customer Public Cloud Environment

schedule.title: Troubleshoot Cloud Networking Like a Pro
schedule.description: OpenStack is a large cloud platform, which can be configured, used and be broken innumerable ways. On the other hand configure networking is usually tricky especially in a large environment both with OpenStack or in general, so most probably you asked the question "Why is my networking not working?" several times already in your life. In this presentation we are going to describe the common problems that can occur and we will list different techniques and systematic approaches to find the solutions to these issues. Whether you are beginner or advanced, if you are struggling much with networking in your cloud, join us to learn new solutions or just to bring home a good troubleshooting guide.
schedule.problem_addressed: Troubleshooting skills for Neutron/networking
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Troubleshooting skills for Neutron/networking

videos.name: Troubleshoot Cloud Networking Like a Pro

schedule.title: Multi-tenancy for Docker Containers With Keystone, and Adding Quota Limits
schedule.description:
Docker containers need multi-tenancy feature with keystone which will help to isolate the containers for different users and tenants. Multi tenancy will avoid users invading other users' containers, since the containers owned will be invisible to other tenants or users except the admin or the owner of the containers.

The proposed approach enables the organization administrator to specify quota limits through keystone ensuring budget targets are adhered to in a pay-as-you-go pricing model. Use keystone to validate the identity of a user's username-password, API key or authentication token.

Proposal is to create a new authentication plugin to talk to keystone and validate the user's credentials.

This security feature allows secure communications between containers. The private networking enables open connectivity within the environment deployed by a given user.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Proposal Authentication:

Use keystone to validate the identity of a user using his username-password, API key or an authentication token. Plan to create a new authentication plugin to talk to keystone and validate the user's credentials

Workflow:

User gets an un-scoped keystone token using the keystone api directly.

The user then sets this token as his password in configfile, and he uses this for all his requests sent to the api server authentication plugin then validate this token against keystone to see if it is valid.

If the token is validated, authentication passes, else it fails

Autherizarion:Map namespaces to keystone projects and used ACLs based on keystone to validate if a user has access to resources within the namespace. This enables us to have multi-tenant clusters, which don't actually require network isolation as of now. We plan to create a new authorization plugin to do this.

Workflow:

The object and its attribute and username is passed on the autherization module.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. How to control the organization cost.

2. How do the deployed containers talk to each other

3. What are the mail files of docker container

4. How to integrate keystone for multi-tenancy for docker containers

5. How to add quota limit for the users of docker containers

6. What benefit they will get by adding keystone to containers

videos.name: Multi-tenancy for Docker Containers With Keystone, and Adding Quota Limits

schedule.title: Live Migrating Nova-Networking to Neutron in Icehouse
schedule.description:
Nova-networking has been a staple of Openstack since nearly the beginning. Still in use by many organizations, it is stable and well tested. As organizations continue to move to a more feature-rich network orchestration framework, Nova-networking is no longer meeting their needs, and Neutron is the future. Unfortunately, there's no clear migration strategy for moving from Nova-networking to Neutron.

In this talk we will:

  • Detail our migration of several live Icehouse environments running nova-networking with the linuxbridge plugin and VLAN network segmentation over to Neutron
  • Share the code and documentation written to achieve this with minimal tenant impact, and
  • Answer questions anyone may have

Migrating from legacy code is always a tough proposition, but by tackling it together it's one which doesn't have to be insurmountable.
schedule.problem_addressed: There is no clear upgrade path from nova-networking to neutron, and even less information about how one might achieve this with minimal tenant impact. We have completed this migration in a live production environment, and believe our experience, and code, is worth sharing.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect to learn strategies for migrating existing nova-network environments over to equivalent neutron deployments. But, most importantly, attendees should leave feeling as though migrating from legacy systems is not an insurmountable proposition, but with a little planning and thinking can be done with relative ease.

videos.name: Live Migrating Nova-Networking to Neutron in Icehouse

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: Datera - OpenStack Cinder delivering Intent-Defined Infrastructure
schedule.description: OpenStack provides an ubiquitous platform for application deployment and scaling. However, for stateful applications the ability to scale is physically bound to the infrastructure capabilities. There is a need to define the application requirements through clean contracts and abstractions to the infrastructure. The underlying infrastructure should translate this intent to best address the requirements for the application. In this session, we present an implementation to enable intent-defined storage for OpenStack through the notion of application templates.

schedule.title: Appformix - The Neighbors Aren't Noisy Anymore
schedule.description:
AppFormix and Intel collaborated to solve the noisy neighbor problem that's become a bigger issue in private cloud than anyone thought it would be. Increasingly dense core counts and the rise of microservices mean that a resource-greedy VM or container will jeopardize the performance of your well-behaved workloads.In this talk you'll learn how AppFormix software has been integrated into Intel Resource Director Technology to deliver performance improvements of more than 50%. It's a real-time monitoring stack for the next generation. Come find out how it keeps noisy neighbors in check.

AppFormix and Intel collaborated to solve the noisy neighbor problem that's become a bigger issue in private cloud than anyone thought it would be. Increasingly dense core counts and the rise of microservices mean that a resource-greedy VM or container will jeopardize the performance of your well-behaved workloads.In this talk you'll learn how AppFormix software has been integrated into Intel Resource Director Technology to deliver performance improvements of more than 50%. It's a real-time monitoring stack for the next generation. Come find out how it keeps noisy neighbors in check.
