Without the option to measure lines of code or number of reviews, it can easily feel like your contributions don't count. For the various manager-types out there (people managers, change & release managers, product or program managers) as well as the individuas in the operations, architecture, and support functions, finding meaningful and helpful ways to contribute can be intidiminating. In the discussion, we'll share what is working, what is challenging, and how we can continue to contribute to the OpenStack effort in the next cycle.

schedule.title: Protecting the Galaxy - Multi-Region Disaster Recovery with OpenStack and Ceph
schedule.description: IT organizations require a disaster recovery strategy addressing outages with loss of storage, or extended loss of availability at the primary site. Applications need to rapidly migrate to the secondary site and transition with little or no impact to their availability.This talk will cover the various architectural options and levels of maturity in OpenStack services for building multi-site configurations using the Mitaka release. We’ll present the latest capabilities for Volume, Image and Object Storage with Ceph as the backend storage solution, and look at the future developments the OpenStack and Ceph communities are driving to improve and simplify the relevant use cases.
schedule.problem_addressed: IT organizations require a disaster recovery strategy addressing outages with loss of storage, or extended loss of availability at the primary site. Enterprise applications needs to be able to survive large scale disasters and rapidly migrate to the secondary site and transition with little or no impact to their availability.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Cinder Backup was designed to easily backup your Cinder volumes to another storage platform including Ceph or Swift.  Cinder volume metadata can be used to backup and restore a volume, allowing backup and restore at another site. We will also cover the community progress supporting backup from OpenStack private cloud to a public cloud.

Volume Replication was first implemented in Juno with the intent to enable volume replication services needed for HA and DR use cases.  However, there were a number of challenges in the initial implementation and as such a second version has been implemented in Liberty.  Volume replication is largely handled by the backend driver, with the API providing basic methods. Ceph’s new RBD mirroring functionality provides one such implementation.

videos.name: Protecting the Galaxy - Multi-Region Disaster Recovery with OpenStack and Ceph

schedule.title: Only You Can Prevent Forest Fires -  A Proactive Approach to Monitoring Your OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description: When the alarms go off and it's your responsibility to solve a problem with your cloud, it's important to have visibility into your deployment.  What if it was possible to see the problems before they happened?  What if it was possible to solve the next issue before the alarm goes off or a customer reports an issue?  Over the past eight months, Time Warner Cable has been using the Monasca project for alerting, capacity planning, problem prediction, and trend analysis.  This talk will cover how we've gone from reactive to proactive, the challenges along our way, and how you can do the same.
schedule.problem_addressed: Monitoring an OpenStack cloud deployment is non-trivial, and improper monitoring can be a waste of resources and time.  But when there's a problem in your cloud, rapid response and resolution can be critical.  This talk will not only discuss how to setup cloud monitoring, but also how take that information and head off problems before they can occur.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: OpenStack users will learn how to overcome the challenges of monitoring their cloud at scale, as well as the tools they can use to get more out of their data.  We will also discuss the important questions behind effective monitoring, such as what information can be acted on, and share real-life examples of how our monitoring has prevented customer outages and eased the life of on-call personnel.

videos.name: Only You Can Prevent Forest Fires -  A Proactive Approach to Monitoring Your OpenStack Cloud

schedule.title: OpenStack and Opendaylight:  The Current Status and Future Direction
schedule.description: One of the biggest use-case of opendaylight use-cases are openstack integration. It has been focused for past releases and still been addressed. In this presentation, the high level overview of the architecture of the integration of opendaygliht and openstack as introduction, and the current status will be shown. What will newly come for Opendaylight Beryllium release and OpenStack Mitaka release like support for BGPVPN and L2gateway for opendaylight, networking-odl rewrite for openstack side. Future plan will be discussed with its challenges. Since our efforts handles both two big project, i.e. opendaylight and openstack, it's a challenge to coordinate two independent release plan assuring the quality. Both components need to be touched. In the second half, how to deploy opendaylight with openstack will be discussed and the development process and how to contribute will shown. At last we will have question time to get feedback for future direction/development process.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack neutron with OpenDaylight backend and its more advanced services.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendee will learn about opendaylight integration with openstack The current status, what will newly come for Mitaka release, what's planned for the next N release and the further future direction of it. Audience will learn only the status, but also development process so that they can give feedback/influence on what should be focused/handled.

videos.name: OpenStack and Opendaylight:  The Current Status and Future Direction

schedule.title: OpenStack + OPNFV: A Collaboration
schedule.description:
Co-presenter: Mark Collier

Having proven itself remarkably well across the IT landscape and enterprise cloud, the open source development model is now being applied full force to overcome the most daunting challenges in networking and NFV. As end users build more agile and cost effective networks that eschew proprietary solutions, they are investing heavily in open source platforms. In order to meet market demand as well as achieve strict carrier-grade requirements, collaboration among open source networking projects is vital. OpenStack has been involved with OPNFV since inception--an integration that is deepening across the communities and leadership of both projects. OpenStack is the Virtualization Integration Manager (VIM) layer in OPNFV and contributes to multiple projects. OPNFV, in turn, contributes requirements, developers and code upstream for features in OpenStack. Join us to learn how this collaboration is accelerating open source NFV and transforming the network.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session addresses the need for open source networking projects to work together in order to meet industry demands amid a rapidly evolving environment. This presentation will show how two major networking projects --OPNFV and OpenStack --have come together to collaborate on accelerating open source NFV and transform the network.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to learn best practices and tips and tricks for cross-collaboration on how to integrate open source networking projects. Via real workd examples, speakers from OPNFV and OpenStack will demonstrate how they are approaching network transformation via open source NFV.

videos.name: OpenStack + OPNFV: A Collaboration

schedule.title: OpenStack for High-Performance Bioinformatics
schedule.description:
This talk will describe the bioinformatics use cases, challenges and experiences of two leading research institutions: the Francis Crick Institute and Cambridge University.

Adam Huffman will describe how the Francis Crick Institute creates HPC clusters on OpenStack for genomics and scales them to 5,000 cores. He will report on the experience of setting up virtual clusters with batch schedulers on OpenStack to provide an HPC environment for life sciences users. These users build complex pipelines comprised of many tools, operating on multi-terabyte datasets, historically on centrally-provided bare-metal clusters. Adam will describe how the problems of reliably constructing such clusters were overcome with OpenStack, and the challenges in achieving high performance on OpenStack with clusters of this size.

Paul Calleja and Wojciech Turek will describe how Cambridge University is building an HPC bioinformatics platform upon OpenStack infrastructure. The performance of this software stack depends on an IO subsystem optimised for data access patterns characteristic to HPC and current bioinformatics workloads in genomics. Current high-throughput technologies such as Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) produce unprecedented scales of data in genomics and clinical projects, with many projects producing petabytes of data. Most existing bioinformatics solutions have problems scaling and dealing efficiently with current data volumes, making it hard to store, analyze, share and visualize the data. Cambridge’s approach focuses on solutions that deliver low-latency and high-throughput access to storage.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session addresses the case of life sciences users who have a lot of existing investment in traditional batch scheduled HPC environments, in terms of knowledge, experience and tooling. Private OpenStack clouds are proliferating in the scientific community and they present an attractive resource for these users. In particular these clouds afford a lot more freedom to the user as compared with traditional clusters, which are tightly controlled. The session will demonstrate the practicality of achieving HPC performance with demanding workloads on OpenStack private clouds.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees of this session will learn how to create a functioning virtual HPC cluster and to scale that cluster up to 5,000 cores, maintaining good performance. Attendees will also learn about:

  • strategies to avoid cattle turning into pets
  • complications with restricted access datasets
  • rescuing instances affected by unreliable underlying storage
  • apparent differences in reliability between filesystems used in compute node instances
  • the need to engage actively with upstream software projects in order to address bugs and missing functionality
  • cultural issues for users
  • user expectations
  • provisioning of complex genomics software pipelines

videos.name: OpenStack for High-Performance Bioinformatics

schedule.title: Private Swift Endpoint
schedule.description:
In some cases, administrators have to restrict outbound reachability of internal tenant network.

Swift endpoints are no exception.

In this talk, we will discuss how we can make workaround to provideaccess to Swift for closed tenant network. Enterprise users who want to keep security needprivate Swift endpoints like VPC endpoints in AWS.

We will show a few methods to enable private Swift endpoints and considerpros and cons.
schedule.problem_addressed:
If outbound access from tenant network is not allowed, but users still need access to Swift, users have to make some workaround.

We will make a comparison of such methods.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
* A few methods to provide access to Swift into the internal tenant network

* Pros and cons of these methods

videos.name: Private Swift Endpoint

schedule.title: Neutron Networking in the Real World -- Sharing Experiences & Lessons Learnt
schedule.description:
In this user panel, we will discuss the OpenStack network deployment experiences of three different enterprise-scale data centers using a Unified Physical + Virtual Neutron Networking architecture.

  • Clemson University: Deploying a production-grade OpenStack Virtual Desktop environment. Experiences with deployment and operation of OpenStack and VmWare on converged data center pods, leveraging multi-tier network segmentation for threat or fault isolation, troubleshooting, monitoring and compliance.
  • Telus: Experiences with deploying a Unified Physical and Virtual networking solution for OpenStack using Mirantis Fuel. Learnings from provisioning, managing and troubleshooting distributed L2 & L3 networking across physical and virtual switch infrastructure.
  • CleanSafeCloud: Meeting performance and resilience requirements of an OpenStack-powered collocated private cloud infrastructure, encompassing IaaS and Object Storage solutions for highly secure applications, leveraging SDN architecture.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack Neutron Networking has come a long way in just a few years. The debates and discussions about the scale and stability of early deployments and the need for validation from a few select super users has given way to in-depth conversations about real life deployment experiences – at enterprises of all sizes and scales.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should expect real world experiences from data center architects who have deployed neutron networks in production.  In addition to scale and resilience of a managing an L2+L3 network from OpenStack Horizon, the panel will discuss the implications of using a unified physical + virtual networking architecture, and the challenges and benefits of using white-box based switching platforms.

videos.name: Neutron Networking in the Real World -- Sharing Experiences & Lessons Learnt

schedule.title: Security Concerns? We’ve Got Your Back and RBAC
schedule.description:
Member or admin.  Do you still only have two roles in your cloud?  Implementing Role Based Access Controls sounds so easy, but how do you do it without disrupting your users? Well, we made the jump with almost no impact.

Modifying roles in a production environment is a journey fraught with peril and screams of horror.  From starting with the community policies through deploying custom roles, we will guide you through:

  • Conceptualizing what authority levels should be required
  • Visualizing authorities throughout the environment
  • Solving the “everyone’s an admin” problem
  • Discovering dependencies between OpenStack services
  • Working around Keystone domains vs. ignorance of domains
  • Planning compartmentalized deployments
  • Modifying Horizon for new roles
  • Implementing backwards compatibility
  • Deploying new policies
  • Cleaning up after yourself

After this talk, you’ll be well prepared to proceed safely with your RBAC implementation.
schedule.problem_addressed: Implementing Role Based Access Controls seems easy, but getting it right without causing large disruptions for users requires much more thought than it may first appear.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn the best practices we've uncovered for deploying RBAC, as well as hear about the real world experience from our own production deployment. After this talk, attendees will be well prepared to proceed safely with RBAC implementations.

videos.name: Security Concerns? We’ve Got Your Back and RBAC

schedule.title: Architecture and Best Practices to Deploy Hadoop and Spark Clusters with Sahara
schedule.description:
Using Big Data environments as analytics engines to gain useful insight on massive amounts of data in a manageable and timely manner can be a complex challenge. Using Sahara as the orchestration tool helps cloud architects provide high-performance production Hadoop and Spark environments enabling private cloud deployments that are easy for data scientists to manage and consume. We will provide a reference architecture for a Hadoop cluster using Intel based systems and Sahara focused on performance and ease of use to answer questions regarding security, storage, and supporting future releases without re-installing.

Attendees will learn:

- Hadoop configurations to best utilize CPU and I/O resources

- Storage Best practices

- New ways to orchestrate a cluster with various Hadoop and Spark workloads

- Published performance benchmark results

- LIfe cycle management
schedule.problem_addressed:
Big Data environments can be inherently complex. Using these environments as analytics engines to gain useful insight on massive amounts of data in a manageable and timely manner is yet another complexity. We’ll show you how we created the wheel, so to speak, so you don’t have to.

This problem addressed in this session is how to deploy data analytics workloads in private cloud, including the needed hardware design, orchestrating multi-flavored data analytics pipelines, and performance tuning considerations for development, test, QA and production analytics workloads. This session provides an overview of advanced features and practices for deploying Hadoop clusters using Sahara as the orchestration tool. We will cover techniques to gain better performance and higher utilization from a given cluster. We will review BigBench and Terasort testing results and how we made sure the deployment provides users with ease of management and adequate performance
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees are expected to have understanding of analytics workloads, some understanding of the Hadoop framework, and knowledge of storage solutions for OpenStack. While attendees with just this knowledge will be able to make use of the information provided, mainly around the return on investment, it is recommended to have some understanding of OpenStack internals.

Attendees will receive a complete overview of:

- Hadoop settings and configuration to best utilize CPU and I/O resources

- Best practices for selection of storage settings

- New ways to submit jobs and orchestrate clusters with various Hadoop distributions

- Spark workloads orchestration

- Published results on different benchmarks used to validate cluster performance

- Life cycle management of deployments

videos.name: Architecture and Best Practices to Deploy Hadoop and Spark Clusters with Sahara

schedule.title: Your CI/CD Infrastructure is a Monolith Too
schedule.description: The container revolution had left our CI/CD infrastructure in need of a serious face-life. See how we’ve containerized our CI/CD infrastructure using Kubernetes on OpenStack. Featuring on-demand spin up, dynamic scaling and siloed workspaces for unit and integration testing.
schedule.problem_addressed: The need for a lightweight CI/CD infrastructure to keep up with containerized app deployments.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Deploying containerized Jenkins and how to build an end-to-end microservice deployment pipeline.

videos.name: Your CI/CD Infrastructure is a Monolith Too

schedule.title: You Must Be 12 Factors High to Ride
schedule.description:
OpenStack is a tool, and tools are meant to do one thing well. Unfortunately, people often use a tool improperly ("Get me a bigger hammer!"). The correct workload for OpenStack is an application that follows the 12 Factor App methodology. We will discuss this methodology and how OpenStack assists in adhering to it.

We will:

  • Explain the 12 Factor App methodology
  • Discuss how the 12 Factor App and OpenStack compliment each other
  • How how adopting the 12 Factor App and OpenStack enhances agility

This session discusses a specific solution that can be used by organizations to increase agility. It is a how to, not a philosophical discussion
schedule.problem_addressed: Many people don’t know what workloads are a good fit for OpenStack. This session will help you understand how you may need to change your software methodology to take advantage of OpenStack and use it to your advantage.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
It will:

  • Explain the 12 Factor App methodology
  • Discuss how the 12 Factor App and OpenStack compliment each other
  • How how adopting the 12 Factor App and OpenStack enhances agility

videos.name: You Must Be 12 Factors High to Ride

schedule.title: Best Practice for Deploying Application with Heat in Production by Deployment Modules and Patterns
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

This presentation will introduce deployment modules, how to use it to quickly deploy complicated applications, will follow agenda below:

1. Obstacles blocking user from using heat templates in real cases

2. Introduce deployment modules, and deployment patterns

3. How to deploy a typical enterprise application by deployment modules which has ability of scaling and HA.

4. Heat stack life-cycle management by deployment modules

5. Best practices for heat templates
schedule.problem_addressed:
Most heat resources are designed based on a very low level of openstack components, it's hard to deploy complicated application. User has to understand each resource's usageand underlying technologies prior to deploy a complicated application. For example, suppose user wants to deploy a cluster which is able to scaling up and scaling down, user has todefine those heat resources at least 5 resources. It also involves various configurations of each resource.It makes heat deployment a tough task.

While our deployment modules consisted of a group of heat resources, are resources at high level, more like objects that are easy understanding and configed. The deploymentmodules come from lots of deployment experience in production. To deploy a cluster for instance, user can directly use cluster module , what he/she to do is providing a few parameters.By using deployment modules, deployment by heat will become easy an and fast.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
For Openstack users, we will provide them an easy deployment way by heat templates, introduce how to deploy enterprise applications by heat templates, I believe it is inspiring news for openstack user, they will be more willing to use heat for their deployment.

For developers in community, especially for heat community, deployment module will be an important direction to promote heat use.

videos.name: Best Practice for Deploying Application with Heat in Production by Deployment Modules and Patterns

schedule.title: OpenStack Astara: A Hands-on Installation & Tutorial Workshop
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

In this 90 minute workshop, some of the key contributors to OpenStack Astara will walk attendees through the installation and configuration of Astara on virtual machines. Attendees will get a better understanding of the various components of Astara.  Attendees will also leave with a working, multi-node VM installation on their laptops for further evaluation and testing.

Attendees will learn:

  • The Astara Reference Architecture
  • How to Install and Configure Astara
  • How to set up Nova and Neutron Integration - Linux Bridge or OVS
  • How to perform day to day network operations tasks
  • Admin user usage of the API, CLI and Horizon UI
  • Advanced Feature functionality
  • Tips and Tricks for using Astara
  • How to Join the OpenStack Astara community of developers.

Come and learn how to simplify your Openstack networking designs.
schedule.problem_addressed: Clarify peoples understanding about Openstack Astara and how it relates to Openstack Networking - Neutron.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendee will learn the following:

  • Astara Reference Architecture
  • How to Install and Configure Astara
  • How to setup Nova and Neutron to Integrate with Astara
  • How to Operate Astara and perform day-to-day operational tasks

videos.name: OpenStack Astara: A Hands-on Installation & Tutorial Workshop

schedule.title: Pristine Machine - Intrinsically secure enterprise clouds
schedule.description: Cloud solutions offer dramatic flexibility through an extensive set of services and related OSS software. However, this flexibly and variability limits OpenStack deployment into mission-critical environments, because of security assurance limitations. In this presentation, we would like to discuss approaches for cloud resource isolation and policy assurance to mitigate these challenges, with an eye towards EAL certification.

Build Your Own Web Portal with OpenStack APIs and Services
schedule.description:
Horizon is the default WebUI for OpenStack clouds but sometimes there is a need for customization to include features such as approval workflows, application catalogs for self-service, or simply the need to add your company logo.

OpenStack clouds, by design, provide a set of rich RESTful APIs which can be leveraged to build your own portal.  In a custom portal, it is also possible to leverage RESTful APIs from other services in your organization to build a holistic control plane for your entire IT environment!

In this talk, we will discuss/demonstrate how to create an IT infrastructure web portal based on OpenStack APIs and also incorporate capabilities exposed by automation tools such as Chef or ServerSpec.
schedule.problem_addressed: Develop your Web Portal, for your company only, using your OpenStack Environment
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees will learn:

1. Introduction to how OpenStack APIs work

2. How to leverage a custom WebUI to automatically create HEAT templates based on user input

3. Integration of automation tools (such as Chef or ServerSpec) with OpenStack services to build an application provisioning/manageement workflow

4. Tips, tricks, and best practices that were learned during implementations for real-world scenarios

videos.name: Build Your Own Web Portal with OpenStack APIs and Services

schedule.title: Open Source NFV: Lessons Learned from End Users
schedule.description:
Panel moderator: Alan Clark

Set to transform the way networks are designed, NFV has seen explosive growth over the past few years, with more telecoms testing PoCs to verify real-world applicability for emerging use cases. Many of the world’s largest communications companies and enterprise network operators—including Orange, Docomo, AT&T and China Mobile—are embracing NFV via open source projects like OPNFV and OpenStack. These communities are tightly integrated and collaborate across projects and teams to innovate rapidly as they work to meet carrier-grade end user requirements and accelerate NFV deployments. In this panel, leading telecoms involved in both OPNFV and OpenStack will discuss emerging NFV use cases; PoCs and testing; how they work with both OpenStack and OPNFV; what’s unique about each project; and what results they’re achieving through open source NFV.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: This panel will address how major telecoms are testing NFV scenarios via open source projects OPNFV and OpenStack, answering the questions of who, what and how open source NFV is being leveraged in the real world.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to learn how OPNFV and OpenStack are helping to make NFV a relatiy via concrete, real-world examples from the industry.

videos.name: Open Source NFV: Lessons Learned from End Users

schedule.title: Ironic: Managing Thousands of Servers in Production
schedule.description:
The challenge of managing physical hardware can be simplified using Ironic bare-metal provisioning, decreasing workload deployment time. In this session, we will address the need for self-service and its benefits over submitting tickets. We’ll also discuss typical data center/infrastructure integration use cases.

We discuss:
- What Ironic is and how it works

- Benefits of using Ironic compared to other provisioning tools

- Challenges and "missing parts" you can encounter using Ironic in production environments, such as:  rack-level awareness for networking (i.e., availability zones for networks); DNS integration; hardware RAID configuration (e.g., extended Ironic Python Agent functionality); server name generation

- Operational issues such as data center networking to accommodate Ironic

Ironic is perceived by many as being immature, since there is a lack of notable experience in using Ironic in production, especially at scale but we’ll share real world large-scale production experience.
schedule.problem_addressed: The challenge of managing physical hardware in a data center can be simplified using Ironic bare-metal provisioning, with the added benefit of decreasing the time it takes for end-users to get their servers deployed with workloads. In this presentation, we will address the need for self-service and its benefits over the old way of submitting tickets. Users can provision their own hardware based on the quota available in a matter of minutes instead of filing IT tickets and waiting for days or weeks. We’ll also discuss typical data center/infrastructure integration use cases.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this session, attendees will learn about:
- What Ironic is and how it works
- Benefits of using Ironic compared to other provisioning tools, such as:
   - Standardized OpenStack REST API
   - Image based provisioning
   - RBAC separations on project/tenant basis
   - VM provisioning
- Challenges and "missing parts" you can encounter using Ironic in production environments, such as:
   - Rack-level awareness for networking (i.e., availability zones for networks)
   - DNS integration
   - Hardware RAID configuration (e.g., extended Ironic Python Agent (IPA) functionality)
   - Server name generation
- Operational issues such as data center networking to accommodate Ironic

videos.name: Ironic: Managing Thousands of Servers in Production

schedule.title: Deploying Lots of Teeny Tiny Telco Clouds
schedule.description: Over the last year at AT&T we have been deploying dozens of OpenStack clouds to host VNFs and other applications central to AT&T's business. This has been a challenging process which has produced enough heroic tales to fill a legendary tome of engineering. In this talk, we will focus on the particular problem of deploying very small form factor, multi-vendor, OpenStack clouds.
schedule.problem_addressed: AT&T has thousands of PoP (Point-of-presence) locations around the world. We were given a mandate to develop an architecture capable of supporting AT&T's application needs and then deploying it in 50+ locations. The catch is, these PoPs are very constrained in terms of space, network and power. Therefore, we need to run a very featureful cloud in a hardware poor environment. This required us to virtualize the entire control plane among other things. We also had to solve the sticky issue of having MaaS, Fuel and vCenter all wanting to do DHCP and PXE boot every single node on the VLAN (we couldn't use multiples). A creative but simple architecture was proposed and implemented that solved these problems in a very clean way. The basic structures that were produced were: a bootstrap process, a simple undercloud capability and an overcloud. The process is completely automated and unattended.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How to deal with multiple DHCPs and PXE booters (multi-vendor) on a single L2 network

How to create a very small form factor bootstrap environment (<100MB)

A complete automation workflow that fulfills the "cloud in a box" ideal

An overview of each tool and it's function in the architectureAnalysis and retrospective from 50+ production deployments

videos.name: Deploying Lots of Teeny Tiny Telco Clouds

schedule.title: Docker 101: Introduction to Docker
schedule.description: This is a comprehensive introduction to Docker, without an analogy of shipping containers. Find out what's happening under the hood, and how containers are different from virtual machines. Learn the difference between Dockerfiles, container images, running containers, terminated containers, Docker Registry, and a demo of the Docker CLI that goes beyond what you learn from the online simulator.
schedule.problem_addressed: Containers are new. This session is intended to help newcominers get up to speed with the concepts of containers, and understand how they are different than virtual machines.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Docker Fundamentals

  • Namespaces
  • Cgroups
  • Container images

Image Repositories

  • Layered images

Container Lifecycle

Docker Demo

  • How you can ealisly create containers from numerous fidderent linux distros
  • How all containers share the same kernel
  • How to launch a container host using docker-machine

videos.name: Docker 101: Introduction to Docker

schedule.title: Python Basics for Operators Troubleshooting OpenStack
schedule.description:
As any OpenStack operator knows a straightforward request, such as creating a VM, requires multiple services to successfully communicate with each other and perform a designated function. When this doesn’t go to plan there are a number of potential log files to analyze, each potentially supplying a piece of the puzzle.

This talk will provide knowledge on how an operator who has minimal experience of the Python programming language can extract the information they need to root cause and resolve issues.
schedule.problem_addressed: Those without some basic knowledge of Python may struggle to debug and root cause failures occurring in an OpenStack environment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Specific areas covered will be:

  • An overview of Python and it’s characteristics as a language
  • The Python logging framework, and its use in OpenStack
  • The threading models of OpenStack services
  • How to read and use a Python stack trace to determine the service responsible
  • How to add additional logging yourself when the service does not provide enough detail

videos.name: Python Basics for Operators Troubleshooting OpenStack

schedule.title: Dragonflow - Neutron Done the SDN Way
schedule.description:
Dragonflow is an open source distributed control plane implementation of Neutron which is an integral part of OpenStack.

Dragonflow introduces innovative solutions and features to implement networking and distributed network services in a manner that is both lightweight and simple to extend, yet targeted towards performance-intensive and latency-sensitive applications.

Dragonflow aims at solving the performance and scale problems in Neutron leveraging lessons Learned from running OpenStack at scale and doing it the SDN way.

We will cover the following topics:

  • Dragonflow introduction and progress
  • Pluggable topology and policy distribution model
  • Supported distributed networking services (DHCP, Routing and more)
  • Innovative and interesting solutions for some hot networking topics:  Security groups, Container networking, Service chaining & topology injection, Integration with smart NICs for h/w offloading
schedule.problem_addressed:
An important use case for Dragonflow is to be an integral part of OpenStack and Neutron, both the implementation and the plugin are under OpenStack governance and located in an official OpenStack project, all running in an open source way and according to OpenStack TC guidelines.

Dragonflow was created in order to solve some of the challenges of running Neutron reference implementation at scale and suggest simple ways to solve them in an SDN way.

We recieve constant feedback and requierments from cloud operators running OpenStack at scale and integrating solutions in Dragonflow to accomodate these.

Dragonflow implements networking services (like Routing, DHCP, Security and more) in a distributed way that fits scaling these services and providing proper HA/Redundancy.

Instead of selecting a specific locked-in solution for control plane distribution, Dragonflow uses a pluggable architecture which allows operator to pick perfect framework for his/her cloud
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
They attendees should get familiar with Dragonflow and hear a complete Introduction to the project.

They should understand the ways Dragonflow is trying to solve the use cases mentioned above.

Information regarding Dragonflow deployments will be shared in addition to complete roadmap plan for future features we plan for the project.

videos.name: Dragonflow - Neutron Done the SDN Way

schedule.title: Shared Filesystems Management (Manila); Forging the Way Ahead
schedule.description: Manila is the OpenStack shared filesystem service that was announced September 2013. In January 2015 it was labeled as an officially incubated OpenStack program. Now with the current stable release in Liberty, Manila is providing the management of file shares (for example, NFS and CIFS) as a core service to OpenStack. Manila currently works with a variety of vendors, including NetApp, Red Hat Storage (GlusterFS), EMC, IBM GPFS, Hitachi, HPE, and on a base Linux NFS server. In this session, we will provide an introduction to the Manila file share service, a description of the logical architecture of Manila and its API structure, examples of use cases, an exploration of whats coming in Mitaka from share replication, LVM, cephfs, data copy service, and a brief demo.
schedule.problem_addressed: We will discuss the generic file sharing driver and how it interfaces with OpenStack and your launched instances. We will talk about the advantages and disadvantages of each of the drivers and where you might use them such as DBaaS, SAP, generic file sharing, VDI etc... We will also be touching on the various concepts with Manila such as share access rules, share network, snapshots and of course whats coming in the future.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees should come away with a good understanding of what Manila is and where best to utilize it in their OpenStack workloads. They will get new insight and ideas about existing Manila concepts and future concepts to help them plan for their next big project or enhance their current ones.

videos.name: Shared Filesystems Management (Manila); Forging the Way Ahead

schedule.title: Bright Computing - High Performance Computing (HPC) and Big Data on demand with Cluster-as-a-Service (CaaS)
schedule.description:
Cluster-as-a-Service (CaaS) is an innovative concept that empowers end users of an OpenStack private cloud to easily create sophisticated, isolated, and secure clustered infrastructure within their private cloud. CaaS deploys a ready-to-use HPC cluster, preconfigured with all required HPC libraries (e.g. MPI, OpenMP, CUDA), compilers, workload managers (e.g. Slurm, LSF, Torque, Grid Engine) and other tools that users need to quickly start running HPC workloads. HPC is only one application -- Bright solutions seamlessly deploy Hadoop/Spark, Ceph, OpenStack, and many other clustered environments “as-a-service”.

Bright will also demonstrate how its turnkey Bright OpenStack™ platform makes it easier than ever to deploy, manage, and monitor OpenStack from a single pane of glass. Leveraging its ten years of experience in deploying, managing and monitoring HPC clusters, the company will also showcase how Bright OpenStack can be leveraged to spin up HPC and Big Data clusters “as a service” (CaaS) inside of an OpenStack private cloud.

videos.name: Bright Computing - High Performance Computing (HPC) and Big Data on demand with Cluster-as-a-Service (CaaS)

Infrastructure: Work session
Why Betfair Chose OpenStack - the Road to Their Production Private Cloud.
schedule.description:
The partnership of Betfair, Redhat and Nuage Networks present the journey from RFP to Production for Betfair's prive cloud.  This 12 month programme has delivered a fully automated, scalable, resillient OpenStack solution.

Betfair's vision was to deliver an API-driven infrastructure encompassing compute, storage, network and application delivery.  This had to be capable of handling the high transactional load of Betfair's day-to-day operations (circa 2.7Bn API calls, 120M daily transactions).

This presentation, delivered by all three partners, walks you through the stages of the programme - from benefits requirements, vendor selection, project design and implementation.

This presentation will be of great use to anyone considering, or having recently started their own OpenStack implementation with a view of their next generation infrastructure as code.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Use case is for those considering a new OpenStack project - or where OpenStack is a contendor for a future infrastructure refresh.

This session will not be overly technical - but will focus on the business requirements and the practical side of defining, scoping and deliering such a project.

Lessons learnt will be frankly discussed - and questions will be encouraged from the audience.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This is a prime chance to benefit from the lessons learnt and overall experience from a large, innovative project delivering a significant advantage in capability.  Betfair operates a large estate and at considerable scale - as such the project was technically challenging and should provide interest to any attendees.

There is particular value to be had from understanding the drivers that led Betfair to chose an OpenStack based solutioin over a more traditional solution.

Atendees will be invited to ask questions to either/all of the 3 partners.

videos.name: Why Betfair Chose OpenStack - the Road to Their Production Private Cloud.

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: SUSE Two-Day Training: OpenStack Administration - Prepare for the Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam (DAY 2 of 2) - AT MAX CAPACITY
schedule.description:
UPDATE: This training is now at MAX CAPACITY.

RSVP Required

This training is two full-days, all day Wednesday and Thursday. Participants must attend both days in order to complete the training.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

This course is designed for system administrators and others who want to learn how to administer an OpenStack Cloud. Participants receive a comprehensive understanding of the tasks necessary to administer an OpenStack cloud and then use common tools that are included with an OpenStack distribution to administer a SUSE OpenStack cloud. This course prepares the participants to take and pass the Certified OpenStack Administrator (COA) exam.

Agenda:

Section 1: Lab Environment Setup

Section 2: Introduction to SUSE OpenStack Cloud

Section 3: Introduction to OpenStack Cloud Administration

Section 4: Work with OpenStack Tenants

Section 5: Work with OpenStack Domains and Groups

Section 6: Work with Cloud Images

Section 7: Work with Software-defined Networks

Section 8: Work with Workload Instances

Section 9: Work with Block Storage

Section 10: Work with Object Storage

Section 11: Orchestrate the Lifecycle of Cloud Applications

 

Section 12: Meter Cloud Infrastructure Utilization

schedule.title: Mirantis Two-Day Training: OpenStack Fuel Administration (FUEL100) (Day 2 of 2) - AT MAX CAPACITY
schedule.description:
UPDATE: This training is now at MAX CAPACITY.

The OpenStack Fuel Administration (FUEL100) course https://training.mirantis.com/instructor-led-training/openstack-fuel-administration/> is a two day course that exposes participants to the required knowledge to understand and effectively leverage Mirantis' OpenStack distribution.

RSVP Required.

This training is two full-days, all day Wednesday and Thursday. Participants must attend both days in order to complete the training.

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

TRAINING INFO:

Install, configure, and maintain an OpenStack computing environment using Fuel The OpenStack Fuel Administration (FUEL100) course is a two day course that exposes participants to the required knowledge to understand and effectively leverage Mirantis' OpenStack distribution. Unlike our other OpenStack course offerings, the FUEL100 course focuses on the Mirantis OpenStack projects: Fuel, Murano, and Sahara. This course is designed to be complementary to the OpenStack Bootcamps and will not overlap in course material. The course focuses on the Fuel deployment environment and will give participants both the theoretical and hands-on skills required to operate Fuel to enable the deployment of OpenStack. The course is broken up into two sections: lectures and labs.
