schedule.title: Red Hat One-Day Training: Red Hat OpenStack Platform Director
schedule.description:
This training is one full day, all day Thursday, April 28th. 

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

TRAINING INFO:

Red Hat OpenStack Platform director (undercloud) is a deployment and lifecycle management tool for your OpenStack environment. In this one-day course, you will learn about the architecture and technology used in the Red Hat OpenStack Platform director. You will deploy the overcloud (Red Hat OpenStack Platform installation) using the Red Hat OpenStack Platform director and expand the OpenStack deployment by adding a compute node. This is hands-on, technical training in which you will deploy the Red Hat OpenStack Platform director and verify its functionality. Attendees should have a system administration background to get the most out this training.

schedule.title: Rackspace One-Day Training: OpenStack Unpacked - AT MAX CAPACITY
schedule.description:
UPDATE: This training is now at MAX CAPACITY.

RSVP Required

This training is one full day, all day Thursday, April 28th. 

Participants will be charged a refundable $50 deposit fee in order to RSVP for the training. The deposit will be paid via credit card on Eventbrite. Upon completion of the training the deposit will be refunded in full. It may take up to 10 business days to process the refund.

OpenStack Unpacked is a course designed for newcomers, both technical and non-technical. This course will introduce you to OpenStack through hands on labs, lectures and in class coaching. Attendees who may be unfamiliar with working on the command line, using API’s or OpenStack in general, will feel comfortable in this environment. Our experienced instructors will guide you step by step to help build your confidence and knowledge surrounding OpenStack. After this course, you will be able to talk OpenStack fluently and also have some hands on experience to back it up.

schedule.title: OPEN O(Orchestration): Integration of NFVO and SDNO Deploy End to End Network Service.
schedule.description:
OPEN-O integrate both SDN-O and NFV-O to provide the end to end network service orchestration, in the case of vCPE/vBRAS, Enterprise, VPN et al, it need to configure broadband and enterprise access by SDN-O(orchestrator), virtual network function like vCPE/vPE router via NFV-O, and VPN tenant connection through DC-O. And one global "O" is proposed to coordinate two "O"s. OOP (OPEN-O Project) has designed a hierarchical "O" to facilitate the deployment. Since two "O"s could share some common modules, two data models Yang and Tosca will be translated between or within each "O", so one open source project would be considered to be proposed.Starting from NFVO which could work with multiple generic VNF Managers(Tacker, et al.) in Openstack, SDN controller (ODL, et al.), and Virtual Resrouce Manager (Openstack, Vmware et al.) to deploy virtual network function. From now on, we are looking into the possbility to implement the SDNO based on the common platform.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: This presentation are targeting the SDN/NFV orchestration to manage end to end network service, the use case like fixed broadband/enterprise access and VPN services, normally it will have multiple domains to coordinate, access network SDN controller will be responsible for configure the policy in both pCPE and Tunnel termination GW, SDN orchestrator will coordinate SDN controller together with NFV-O to configure VNF like vCPE and vBRAS, even Service Function Chaining.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The architecture of OPEN-O, how NFV-O is implemented, and how VNFM like tacker works with NFV-O, the process of NFV orchestration. This presentation will demonstrate how both fixed and mobile network VNFs will be configured by OPEN-O, how network service is orchestrated.Some VNFs are in one Telecom Integrated Cloud(TIC), other VNFs are deployed in a different TICs, the location of VNFs will be based on the location of end to end network infrastructure.

videos.name: OPEN O(Orchestration): Integration of NFVO and SDNO Deploy End to End Network Service.

schedule.title: Orchestrated Containerization with OpenStack
schedule.description: Initial cloud designs were based upon the assumption that hardware emulation via the hypervisor was to be the most significant building block of cloud compute infrastructure. Many of those clouds were built without a workload in mind, and with an “if you build it they will come”mentality. They often failed to show value to the business. With the emergence of containerization, rich orchestration like Kubernetes and container optimized operating systems, rather than bringing workloads to the cloud, we can bring the cloud to the workloads. The benefits of orchestrated container based cloud approaches are manifold – workloadsare portable between clouds, clouds can quickly be built using existing bare metal, legacy virtualization or next generation cloud providers like OpenStack, Microsoft Azure or Amazon AWS. Further integration of DevOps via PaaS only serves to enhance the organizational benefit of the non-disruptive hybrid cloud approach.
schedule.problem_addressed: How to successfully use containerization not only with openstack but across hybrid cloud scenarios, with a workload across openstack and Azure or AWS. There is still a lot of confusion about what containers can be used for with OpenStack beyond new application development. There are multiple workload scenarios.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How to use containers with OpenStack

How to develop, deploy and manage hybrid workloads across OpenStack and public clouds.

How to leverage container standards, like Kubernetes, in implementing hybrid containerization strategies.

How to use Ansible in these scenarios.

Different architectural designs for hybrid containerization

videos.name: Orchestrated Containerization with OpenStack

schedule.title: The Notorious M.T.U.
schedule.description:
The maximum transmission unit (MTU) defines the maximum size of IP packets sent over a network. Similar to physical networks, neutron contains a variety of layer-2 and layer-3 components that include MTU parameters. Improperly configuring neutron MTU parameters or options that impact MTU parameters can degrade network performance or cause packet loss in obscure places. We plan to cover the following topics:

  • Introduction to MTU: What is it and why does it matter? What is path MTU discovery?
  • Example of valid and invalid MTU configurations on a physical network.
  • Relate physical networks to virtual networks.
  • Discuss neutron MTU problems using both the Linux bridge and Open vSwitch agents on physical networks with 1500 and 9000 byte MTUs.
  • Discuss our solution to these problems.
schedule.problem_addressed: Address operator difficulty with neutron when using overlay networks (VXLAN, GRE, etc.) or physical networks with MTUs larger than 1500. The current "tribal knowledge" fix of simply increasing the MTU of all physical network components above 1500 and leaving all the virtual network components at 1500 shows the failure of neutron to manage MTU in a sane fashion. Additionally, it prevents instances from realizing performance gains of using jumbo frames on 10+ Gbps physical network infrastructure.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Operators learn about MTU, impacts of improper MTU parameters on both physical and virtual networks, neutron MTU problems, and how to properly configure neutron MTU in various environments.

videos.name: The Notorious M.T.U.

schedule.title: Cloud Platform for IoT: Designing and Evaluating Large-Scale Data Collecting and Storing Platform
schedule.description:
Internet of Things is a hot topic today. Many companies are trying to create new business applications on a concept of IoT such as smart city, connected vehicle or smart grid. The platform for IoT applications has some unprecedented characteristics: (1) needs to accept huge number of connections simultaneously (2) needs to be highly reliable and secure (3) needs to be highly scalable.

We have designed, prototyped and evaluated a highly reliable IoT platform for collecting and storing large-scale data.

In this session, we will explain our use case and architecture of IoT platform. We are tackling the following very high requirements during the process of prototyping and evaluating the platform.

  • Receiving and storing messages from over 10M clients concurrently
  • Highly reliable architecture of message broking without losing messages
  • Instant scale-out to process burst traffic rapidly

We will also discuss how we can adopt OpenStack to IoT backend and share ideas for its enhancement.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Finding an architecture to achieve the following trade-off requirements at the same time.

  • High transaction, massive connectivity and huge data amount
  • High reliability
  • High availability
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Overview of IoT Platform
  • Architectural points of IoT Platform for data collection and store
  • Pitfall of designing IoT Platform from our experience
  • How to extend OpenStack for IoT use case

videos.name: Cloud Platform for IoT: Designing and Evaluating Large-Scale Data Collecting and Storing Platform

schedule.title: Swift Middlewares - What Are They?
schedule.description: OpenStack Swift already addresses many wide range of features and solves challenges that come with storage to a great extent. However there can be users and operators with new use cases for their specific needs and would wish to have them in Swift. It is in this scenario, a middleware comes to your rescue and lets you add your own significant feature by extending Swift capabilities. Many features of swift are implemented as middlewares. It would be worthwhile to understand what they are, how they are implemented and how do they communicate with Swift.
schedule.problem_addressed: Leveraging Swift middleware's ability to address custom requirements
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This session gives an introduction to python wsgi middlewares, a sum-up of existing swift middlewares, and presents sample python middleware code. By the end of this, you should be able to understand how python wsgi middlewares work and how you could use this capability to implement your own feature in Swift.

videos.name: Swift Middlewares - What Are They?

schedule.title: Application CI/CD on OpenStack - Building a Solution Using Jenkins and OpenStack Solum
schedule.description: Continuous integration and continuous delivery are important aspects in today's agile and iterative application development methods. Systems such as Jenkins have become pillars of the continuous integration movement providing a general framework to run application-specific tests. On the other hand, continuous delivery has always remained as a challenge. This is especially true if the deployment target is an OpenStack environment which involves several moving parts. In this talk we will present a CI/CD solution that we have built using Jenkins for CI and OpenStack Solum for CD for testing and deploying applications to OpenStack clouds.
schedule.problem_addressed: Organizations these days typically have some sort of CI setup for testing their applications. At the same time, they may be using OpenStack or considering to use OpenStack. One of the problems that they typically face is how to integrate their existing CI setup with the OpenStack infrastructure. Ideally they want to be able to continue using their existing tools and systems and leverage the features and capabilities provided by OpenStack. For instance, they may want to keep using Jenkins for their CI setup and be able to seamlesly deploy their tested applications to OpenStack. In this session we are addressing the problem/use case of how an organisation can continue to use their existing CI infrastructure based on Jenkins and utilize OpenStack Solum for continuous delivery of their applications to OpenStack clouds.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees would learn the following:

- Different architectural options of integrating Jenkins-based CI workflows with OpenStack Solum

- The setup required in Jenkins

- Capabilities of OpenStack Solum that enable seamless application deployment

- Lessons that we learned in building this CI/CD solution consisting of Jenkins for CI and OpenStack Solum for CD.

videos.name: Application CI/CD on OpenStack - Building a Solution Using Jenkins and OpenStack Solum

schedule.title: Managing OpenStack in a Cloud-native Way
schedule.description: Openstack control services are usually deployed all together on dedicated high density hardware and using traditional clustering software to provide high availability. Swisscom took a different approach and, embracing modern distributed application architecture principles, untangled all the various components into separate and whenever possible horizontally-scalable entities. This way we reduced complexity of managing larger fail-over clusters, as well as eased deployment, maintenance and lifecycle. We will introduce our design, our reasoning behind the taken approach, as well as dive into some of the problems we encountered and talk about still existing roadblocks for a true cloud-native deployment of OpenStack management services.
schedule.problem_addressed: The official openstack HA guide advises on 2 different architectures: pacemaker or keepalived, while the latter is seen as optimized for active/active setups. Nevertheless, a lot of distributions, as well as installers, usually come with the pacemaker model as their default option. Swisscom took a different approach and, embracing modern distributed application architecture principles, untangled all the various components into separate and whenever possible horizontally-scalable entities. But we didn't stop there, and looking for a cost-effective and eficient solution, those distributed entities were deployed as virtual machines, which also added a new layer of high availability thanks to well known capabilities of the virtualization technologies.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Essentially, what we are able to show and discuss is an alternative design of how to manage your OpenStack services, which we verified in multiple production deployments. Although, the initial goal was to have a pacemaker-free deployment, we also hit various boundaries of the maturity, as well as the cloud-native nature of some of the components. Over the last year, we worked on the various components with these drawbacks and we will show how we improved the architecture for an overall better resilience by moving more and more towards fully active/active. We will introduce our design, our reasoning behind the taken approach, as well as dive into some of the problems we encountered and talk about still existing roadblocks for a true cloud-native deployment of OpenStack management services.

videos.name: Managing OpenStack in a Cloud-native Way

schedule.title: Neutron Address Scopes
schedule.description:
An exciting new feature was just added to OpenStack Neutron in the Mitaka release; it's called address scopes.  Address scopes build from the subnet pools feature added in Kilo.  While subnet pools give us a mechanism for controlling the allocation of addresses to subnets, address scopes give Neutron a way to know where addresses are viable.  They are also the thing within which addresses are not allowed to overlap.

In this talk, we will give a quick review of subnet pools and then talk about how they support address scopes.  Address scopes are key to overcoming the problem of "bring your own addressing" (BYOA) and are instrumental in determining where traffic should be blocked or where net address translation (NAT) should be applied (or not).  This is especially important when designing your cloud for IPv6.

Finally, we will briefly discuss the relationship between address scopes and two other exciting new features in Neutron:  "BGP dynamic routing" and "routed networks."
schedule.problem_addressed:
When Neutron began, users were expected to specify the addresses to use when they create subnets. I call this “bring your own addressing” or BYOA. This was not ideal for a couple of reasons.

1. It put a burden on end users to manage their address usage.
2. It made it impossible to know where addresses are viable.

The first limitation was solved with the addition of subnet pools in Kilo.

The second limitation effectively led to the decision to NAT everything between tenant networks and the external network in Neutron routers. Think about it this way, the cloud operator has no way of knowing where the addresses on the tenant networks came from, so the only valid assumption to make is that they’re all private addresses and are not viable anywhere else.

There is increasing demand to be able to route tenant networks on the external network.  First, tenants have to disable NAT on their routers.  Second, operators have to trust that tenants are all using the right addresses.

With address scopes, you can set up the scopes for tenants to pull from. Then, since Neutron routers understand address scopes, they won’t NAT between these networks and my external network as long as the scopes match. They’ll just do straight routing.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn when and how to apply address scopes.  They will also learn how address scopes fit in to other exciting projects such as Mitaka's BGP dynamic routing work, and Newton's routed networks.

videos.name: Neutron Address Scopes

schedule.title: Win The Future: OpenStack Deployment Practice among College Students for Innovation Contest
schedule.description: In 2015, Intel took the chance of sponsoring the 8th Intel-Cup National Collegiate Software Innovation contest in China to promote OpenStack by defining the theme to be User Experience Innovation Based on Cloud Service. The college students, who are mainly from school of software and new to OpenStack, were required to set up cloud environment on nested virtualization of a rack in a day, deploy their innovative applications on it and then showcase the demonstrations to the judges. However, we found it was not easy for them to deploy OpenStack as their infrastructures of the innovations, especially for network. We made a survey amongst all the teams, summarized the feedbacks, and analyzed the results, in order to try to find the weaknesses and the reasons why OpenStack is not easy to use to some extent. At the OpenStack summit, we hope to share those results with the audience and think about how OpenStack wins the next generation together with the community.
schedule.problem_addressed: For the 8th Intel-Cup National Collegiate Software Innovation contest in China, 56 Chinese universities from all over China, more than 2000 students, including all top schools of software created 101 software applications on top of OpenStack, after learning OpenStack and practicing deployment on their personal computers during March to November. In the final round of the contest, around twenty teams were asked to deploy OpenStack on the rack as their infrastructure of the innovations in a day and we made a survey amongst them. The presentation will introduce the background, the process, and the final results of the contest based on the cloud, and most important, show all of the answers to the questionnaires, what the problems which the student faced are, and statistics and analysis for all failed deployments, which might expose some of the drawbacks in the OpenStack deployment and installation, from user experience point of view.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: As a member of the community, the attendees expect to know how the innovation contest based on cloud in China went, how the people are doing to win the next generation for OpenStack, and how OpenStack practice went among the college students which are new to OpenStack. The attendees also expect to know what kind of problems the students faced by treating them as experienced people at IT and computer science but new to the OpenStack project, and further think about why it is not convenient for users to deploy OpenStack and how we are going to improve thru the survey.

videos.name: Win The Future: OpenStack Deployment Practice among College Students for Innovation Contest

schedule.title: Deploy Microservices Architecture on OpenStack using Kubernetes, Docker, Flannel and etcd
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

A microservices software architecture is as an approach to developing a single application as a suite of small services, each running in its own process and communicating with lightweight mechanisms, often an HTTP resource API. These services are independently deployable and scalable by fully automated deployment machinery and each service provides a firm module boundary with a minimum of centralized management. You’ve heard enough, and you are so ready to give this architecture a try, right? This hands-on lab will show you how to build it and will walk you through step-by-step deployment of Kubernetes, Docker, Flannel and etcd on OpenStack to get you started.

Please bring a laptop with a web browser and an ssh client (Terminal, Putty, etc).
schedule.problem_addressed: Run Microservices Architecture using Kubernetes, Docker, Flannel and etcd on OpenStack
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Step-by-step deployment of Kubernetes, Docker, Flannel and etcd on OpenStack

videos.name: Deploy Microservices Architecture on OpenStack using Kubernetes, Docker, Flannel and etcd

schedule.title: Configure, Deploy and Troubleshoot Distributed Virtual Routers with DVR SNAT HA in a Multi-Node Environment
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

This session would be a Hands-on Workshop that would provide an opportunity for every attendees to get their hands wet on configuring, deploying, and troubleshooting Distributed Virtual Routers with DVR SNAT HA in OpenStack Neutron. This would eventually make the Users' job easier in understanding the deployment scenarios and the internals which will enable a quicker adoption rate.

In this session we will walk you through

• Multi-node installation of devstack.

• Enable DVR support on the Controller as well as on the Agents.

• Configure different nodes such as DVR enabled Compute Node and Service Node.

• Deploy distributed Routers.

• Configure FloatingIP and walk through the iptables rules in the FIP namespaces.

• Walk through the OVS flow rules.

• Configure DVR SNAT HA.

• Walk through the fail over of SNAT from master to slave.

• Provide additional troubleshooting tips.

NOTE: Laptops are required for this session.
schedule.problem_addressed: Hands on lab on DVR SNAT HA feature will help operators & devlopers in undestaing feature as well as deploying in a real openstack deployment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: From this session, attendees will be able to learn and get hands on experience on configuring, deploying and troubleshooting DVR SNAT HA feature in the Neutron.

videos.name: Configure, Deploy and Troubleshoot Distributed Virtual Routers with DVR SNAT HA in a Multi-Node Environment

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: Fuel: Work session
Infrastructure: Work session
Swift: Work session
Kolla: Work session
Security: Work session
OpenStackAnsible: Work session
Nova: API (continued)
Glance: Work session
Neutron: Community track: stadium evolution
Barbican: Work session
Heat: Software deployment refinements
Mistral: Work session
Keystone: Testing
Trove: Trove Container Support, and using snapshots for backups
Documentation: Contributor Guide
Cinder: Work session
Deploying Neutron Provider Networking on Top of a L3 Provider Network Using BGP-EVPN
schedule.description: This discussion will cover how to deploy Openstack Neutron using provider networking on top of a layer-3 clos network where layer-2 is terminated in each rack. In order to span the provider network across multiple racks we leveraged BGP-EVPN and VXLAN tunneling in the ToR switches. Our design allows us to scale a single Openstack region to 400 compute nodes and over 30,000 VMs. It also enables us to natively bridge bare-metal hosts into the same provider network. We are able to run PCI and non-PCI workloads on the same physical infrastructure using VRFs to segment the different security tiers. We will also present benchmarks on the performance and scale of BGP-EVPN.
schedule.problem_addressed: Scale a provider network model over a layer-3 underlay network and also enable running highly secure and regular workloads running on the same physical infrastructure.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Deployment model on how to scale Openstack to handle large enterprise workloads. Challenges and possible solutions on how to provide segmentation requirements for running highly secure and non-secure workloads on the same cloud infrastructure.

videos.name: Deploying Neutron Provider Networking on Top of a L3 Provider Network Using BGP-EVPN

schedule.title: Horizon: Work session
Developer Marketing and Relations: Convincing The 'Kingmakers' to Give a Crap About You
schedule.description: Developers are the new Kingmakers, but what are the current best and worst practices for developer marketing and relations? Today developers drive the PoCs and early adoption that make or break your product or service, and exert a huge amount of influence on the buying process. And once you've made the sale they are the ones you depend on to make sure you're a critical piece of your customers' stack. If you're in "cloud" it's highly likely that you need to reach developers. The experts on this panel will tell you how they do it, complete with stories of things gone wrong and gone right. Find out which of the current mediums (blogs, docs, social media, conferences, etc.) are the most effective, and walk away with practical, actionable tips for currying the favor of all those flip-flop wearing, overly hair-tinted code monkeys that seem to keep killing your chance at signing a deal.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack has done a great job educating and attracting IT managers, cloud operators and sys-admins, but it's time to address next level users--developers--who are the ultimate fickle customers.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Marketers and product managers in the OpenStack ecosystem will learn why developers are such an important target and how to reach them.

videos.name: Developer Marketing and Relations: Convincing The 'Kingmakers' to Give a Crap About You

schedule.title: Optimising NFV Service Chains on OpenStack Using Docker
schedule.description:
Docker in the recent past has gained a lot of attention given the simplification and ease of use it provides to the existing container technology. It comes with its plethora of advantages, both technical and otherwise. It is lightweight, open, secure and backed by a strong community of developers and promoters.

Of late, even the network functions which were traditionally run on the hardware boxes since ages are being rewritten in software defined networking model. This brought forward a paradigm shift in running these functions on Virtual Machines and are now being ported as Docker Instances. This paradigm shift is bringing around a change in the way we have been looking at network functions and deploying them. There is lot of scope for improved utilization, programmability, and better scalability.

But this change also comes with a new set of challenges. We are trying to identify and solve some of them here.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed:
NFV service chains running on virtual machines often introduce extra hops in the L2 network and L3 network before the packets finally reach the destination. Running NFVs as virtual machines brings other compute and shared storage requirements which need to be addressed in the architecture.

Taking advantage of recent advances in Docker and attempts to build NFVs on containers, we would like to propose an architecture which would increase localization of the service chains and bring them nearer to the tenant VMs. This would reduce the latency introduced by networks and un-complicate the over all architecture.

This also results in better utilization of available resources and improved scalaibility.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Beginners of SDN and NFV can learn about basics of traditional service chaining and the challenges that are introduced by using them in a virtualized environment or a cloud based deployment.

Service providers and Enterprise product owners can gain from the approach to re-evaluate their deployment and look to improve their performance and scalability

Telecom companies can re-evaluate their Bill Of Material and reduce CAPEX and OPEX

Docker enthusiasts and open source developers will have a lot to gain from the session

videos.name: Optimising NFV Service Chains on OpenStack Using Docker

schedule.title: Mapping Real Networks to Physical Networks, Segments, and Logical Networks in Neutron
schedule.description: In this talk we will dive into the details of how Neutron maps a logical network into underlying network infrastructure with the ML2 plugin. We will explain the difference between physical networks, segmentation types, segments, and logical networks. Then we will show how a Neutron network created via the API uses these components to tell the agents on each compute node how to actually put the packets on the wire. Finally, we will talk about the assumptions Neutron currently makes about segments and how they are being adjusted during the Mitaka and Newton cycle to work with restricted L2 topologies without overlays. If you've ever seen the error "Unexpected vif_type=binding_failed" or hate troubleshooting overlays, this is the talk for you!
schedule.problem_addressed: Teaching operators about the fundamental configuration values that Neutron uses to determine how to put packets on the network. Additionally, we will cover how these are being changed in the next two cycles to allow L3 topologies frequently used by large deployers. One of the most common issues to troubleshoot for new deployers is getting these configuration values correct. With a good understanding of what they do, fixing these issues should be much easier.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• How Neutron maps packets from logical Neutron networks to packets on the real network infrastructure underneath.
  • How to troubleshoot port binding failures that prevent VMs from booting
  • How Neutron is adapting to support more diverse operator network topologies

videos.name: Mapping Real Networks to Physical Networks, Segments, and Logical Networks in Neutron

schedule.title: Tacker - Building an Open Platform for NFV Orchestration
schedule.description:
Virtualizing Network Functions is going mainstream in different Telecom operator networks. Come and learn from this talk from the OpenStack Tacker team on how Tacker project has provided a viable community built opensource software for NFV Orchestration. Tacker project is wrapping up its third release for Mitaka with many key features:

  • Tacker Multi-Site allows Operators to place, manage and monitor VNFs in multiple OpenStack Clouds
  • Tacker Service Function Chaining API for a VNF level service-chaining backed by an SDN Controller
  • TOSCA Parser integration brings industry's first OASIS NFV Profile Standards based TOSCA Orchestrator
  • Enhanced VNF Placement placing VNFs the most efficient way with CPU-Pinning, NUMA topology awareness, etc

Beyond Mitaka, Tacker project is embarking onto new areas - Network Service Orchestration, VNF Auto Scaling, etc. Audience will also learn how Tacker is being incorporated into OPNFV deliverables and in NFV Information Model Standardization efforts.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: NFV Orchestration area is currently dominated by proprietary products. The tools required to operate a Telco Private Cloud for NFV has so far came only from select network vendors in proprietary offerings. Opensource efforts so far has been fragmented in this area. Some opensource offerings in this area are still single vendor solutions. With a need to orchestrate and integrate VNFs from multiple vendors and be applicable to a diverse set of Global Telco Operators' such solutions doesn't make sense. Industry needs a community built orchestration software stack where Operators and VNF vendors can come together to provide requirement and participate in the development. OpenStack Tacker project addresses such a gap in the current opensource landscape.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
1. Feature set of an NFV Orchestration Software
  2. Features of OpenStack Tacker project
  3. Roadmap of OpenStack Tacker project
  4. Community behind building the opensource NFV Orchestration
  5. How Tacker is designed into OPNFV projects and deliverables ?

videos.name: Tacker - Building an Open Platform for NFV Orchestration

schedule.title: Monitoring Swift ++ (incl Nagios, Elasticsearch, Zabbix, & more)
schedule.description:
Monitoring of infrastructure and applications is near and dear to operators, and a Swift object storage cluster is no exception. Prevention is always the best medicine, and one needs to know what the environment is doing and how it is doing at all times. Operators have many systems in place which can also monitor Swift as a means of learning from cluster behaviour and predicting issues.

This session covers several popular ways of setting up continuous monitoring of your infrastructure and using your preferred tools for real time alerts for failures and stress conditions is a requirement. In the past few years organizations have started to move from monitoring solutions that detect a certain state and alert on it, to more dynamic solutions like Nagios, Elasticsearch, Zabbix, Logstash, Kibana (ELK) stack and more. Attendees will see hands-on examples for how to monitor an existing Swift cluster.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack makes for a solid foundation, but does not provide a great variety of choice for management and monitoring by default. As such, users look for other open source and vendor management tools to complement their environment. What's more, operators want to use their existing or preferred tools to manage their infrastructure.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This session is DevOps engineers or anyone who wants to learn more about how they can use their favorite tools to monitor Swift. The session includes real examples beyond just the theory of how monitoring can be done.

videos.name: Monitoring Swift ++ (incl Nagios, Elasticsearch, Zabbix, & more)

schedule.title: Extending DVR to Route Intra-Tenant Traffic Between Bare Metal Servers and Virtual Compute Instances
schedule.description:
The current Distributed Virtual Router (DVR) implementation supports routing traffic between virtual instances and routing traffic to external networks that support the OVS plugin. For the last couple of cycles, DVR has gained momentum within the developer and user community and has matured to scale and support other deployment models. For certain workloads inclusion of bare metal servers into a cloud deployment is almost a must. Therefore, it is now time to extend the DVR routing capability to route the traffic to and from the bare metal servers managed by OpenStack Ironic.

In this talk, we will be presenting:

1. How OpenStack Ironic connects bare metal servers to the neutron networks.

2. A proposal on how DVR can be extended to enable routing of data traffic between the virtual machines that reside in VLAN or VXLAN networks in the cloud and the bare metal servers managed by Ironic that reside in a different VLAN segment.
schedule.problem_addressed: There are a number of use cases best served by including a limited number of bare metal servers along with large number of virtual instances for a workload deployed in the cloud. For instance, it could be for extreme reliability, performance or to host a non-scalable properietary application. A classic three-tier application with a data tier hosted on bare metals and rest of the tiers in the cloud virtual instances. For security reasons, or due to an organizational policy structure, the provider may want to keep the virtual workload and the bare metal servers in different VLAN segments, and this is where the DVR will help in routing the traffic between the two.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn:

1. Bringing the bare metal servers into the OpenStack cloud using OpenStack Ironic2. Limitation on having the virtual instances and the bare metal servers in the same VLAN segment.

2. Routing between the virtual instances and the bare metal servers using DVR when the virtual instances and the bare metal servers reside in different VLAN segments.

videos.name: Extending DVR to Route Intra-Tenant Traffic Between Bare Metal Servers and Virtual Compute Instances

schedule.title: Which is the Best Way to Deploy Your Application on OpenStack?
schedule.description:
There are many projects and ways to deploy applications on OpenStack as the following.

  • Glance
  • Glance + cloud-init
  • Glance + Configuration management tool such as Puppet, Chef or Ansible
  • Heat
  • Heat + Configuration management tool such as Puppet, Chef or Ansible
  • Murano
  • Murano with plugin
  • Community App Catalog
  • Solum

Which is the best way to deploy your application on OpenStack? In this session, we first explain each OpenStack project, related softwares, and their relations. Then we will show the pros and cons according to the way to deploy applications from several viewpoints.
schedule.problem_addressed:
There are many projects and ways to deploy applications on OpenStack. OpenStack user can't choose the way to deploy applications. We address this issue. we will show the pros and cons from several viewpoints.

For developer:

  • Integration with other OpenStack services
  • Integration with non-OpenStack services
  • Application version management
  • Life cycle management(integration with CI system, integration with the development environment, deploy automatically to staging, production environments and so on)

For deployer:

  • Deploy applications based on templates which represent dependence of applications and relations
  • Auto or manual scale
  • Monitoring
  • Logging
  • Deploy from UI

For example, Murano integrated with Mistral and Congress, and has plugin architecture to integrate with non-OpenStack services in MuranoPL. Heat orchestrates other OpenStack projects as resources, and also has plugin architecture to extend capabilities.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees expect to learn the project outline related to deploying applications. And From our pros and cons of the way to deploy applications, attendees expect to learn appropriate ways to deploy applications.

videos.name: Which is the Best Way to Deploy Your Application on OpenStack?

schedule.title: Configure, Debug and Install OpenStack Trove
schedule.description:
This session covers multi database deployment, configuration and debugging on OpenStack Trove. Now Trove supports more datastores than before. this session is about educating OpenStack community on Trove. The session also demonstrate some interactions with the Trove API including a demonstration of a deployment with a relational database (MySQL) and a non-relational database (MongoDB). This session contains demos on configuration, installation and debugging. 

 

 

Benefits over traditional databases.

1. Ease of deployment and use

2. Easy to configure and deployment

3. Help reduces cloud operational costs
schedule.problem_addressed:
various ways to congfigure trove

various types of configurations

debugging installations
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
How to configure Trove with Mysql and Mongo databases.  

debug and verifying the log information about trove, mysql and mongo db

various processes of trove, mysql and mongo db

Running some of the E2E tests

videos.name: Configure, Debug and Install OpenStack Trove

schedule.title: Quantifying the Noisy Neighbor Problem in Openstack
schedule.description:
Two of the desirable features for private clouds are better control and predictable performance. Although public clouds have been extensively researched to characterize their unpredictable performance, private clouds have received less scrutiny.

In this talk, we will present how production workloads interfere with each other in an Openstack based cloud. We draw lessons from a several month long study of running workloads in different configurations on highly available implementation of Openstack. We study the impact of noisy neighbors on the network and storage IO performance of applications. We also look at the performance metrics of Openstack control plane and how the API calls are impacted with more number of entities like networks, routers, VMs, volumes. Our study relies on a tool that we developed to create clean and noisy workload deployments, using micro-benchmarks as well as enterprise workloads such as Hadoop, Jenkins and Redis.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Noisy neighbour is a well known problem in public clouds. Users have often complained about high variance in performance for their workloads. Private cloud based on Openstack should be able to provide better noise isolation and performance predictability. Understanding the impact of workloads on each other is critical in a cloud deployment.

 

So far this hasn't been studied for an Openstack deployment. We did a long term study with different micro and macro workloads to understand the impact of noisy neighbours on each other. Specifically, we focused on the network and storage resources, since they are shared across hosts. We show that Openstack by itself does not provide any isolation and it needs to be bilt on top. We also look at the performance of Openstack APIs as we scale the number of entities in the system and show that the performance degrades with more number of entities like VMs, routers, networks etc. Finally, we highlight some of the optimizations to fix these problems.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn about the following three topics:

1) A novel tool that we developed to generate and collect workload metrics in an automated manner. The tool can put workloads across a set of hosts to evaluate different networking configurations such as VMs on same/different host and same/different subnet. Using the tool, we also created set ups with zero or more routers for VM traffic and different storage backends in terms of a local and shared storage system.

2) A performance evaluation study of various interesting configurations in terms of network topologies, CPU/memory over-commitment and storage topologies. The data is collected over several weeks and consists of thousands of data points for different configurations.

3) Based on this study, we show that there is quite a bit of interferance in a general Openstack based cloud. We did the root cause analysis of these problems and suggest various optimizations and best practices to fix these problems.

videos.name: Quantifying the Noisy Neighbor Problem in Openstack

schedule.title: The Open Container Initiative, the OpenStack Magnum & Kuryr Projects, the CNCF, and You!
schedule.description:
The technology industry has been abuzz about cloud workload containerization since the open source Docker project became a phenomenon in early 2014. 

Meanwhile, an OpenStack Containers Team was formed and the Magnum project launched to provide users with a convenient Containers-as-a-Service solution for OpenStack environments. 

As the potential of both technologies emerged, many wanted to see shared governance over the baseline container specification and runtime technology to ensure an open cloud ecosystem. 

This past December, two new groups were launched with a goal of creating open, industry standards. The first called the Open Container Initiative (http://www.opencontainers.org), and the second called the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (http://cncf.io)
schedule.problem_addressed:
Hear from subject matter experts from IBM and NetApp, who will share real world experiences, including:

So how will OpenStack Magnum influence - and be influenced by - the new OCI & CNCF groups?

Why are the OCI & CNCF under the stewardship of the Linux Foundation?

What is the scope of the OCI effort, and how does it differ from the CNCF?

What project goals and/or principles will guide their respect works?
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attend this session to learn the following: 

A brief history of the open container ecosystem and the major benefits that containerization provides

An overview of the Magnum CaaS plugin architecture and design goals

Insider details on the the progress of the Linux Foundation Open Container Initiative (and the related Cloud Native Computing Foundation)

What it all means for deploying container orchestration engines on your cloud with OpenStack Magnum

videos.name: The Open Container Initiative, the OpenStack Magnum & Kuryr Projects, the CNCF, and You!

schedule.title: Keystone: Work session
Fuel: Work session
Using a Service VM as an IPv6 vRouter
schedule.description:
IPv6-enabled OPNFV is a meta-distribution of platform with de-facto provisioning and configuration of IPv6, upon which test harness, additional components and functional blocks and/or tools can be built and integrated. This presentation will review a gap analysis with IPv6 features in OpenStack and Open Daylight, and a novel use case of supporting the capability of an IPv6 vRouter on a VM in OpenStack + Open Daylight environment. The VM is capable of (1) advertising IPv6 Router Advertisements (RA) to the VMs on the internal network; and (2) IPv6 Forwarding (i.e., North-South traffic). This novel use case expands IPv6 vRouter capability to any VM and allows for any 3rd-party solution, e.g. IPv6 vRouter VNF, as an alternative of Neutron Router or ODL Router. Thus it enables open innovation. Various aspects in deployment, configuration, operation, and the potentials of new business scenarios will be described.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: There are gaps and challenges in supporting IPv6 in integrated environment of OpenStack + Open Daylight. The use of Neutron Router is based on Linux namespace, and ODL Router is based on OVS flow table. This presentation reviews the gaps identified. More importantly this presentation introduces a novel use case of supporting the capability of an IPv6 vRouter on a VM in OpenStack + Open Daylight environment, which expands IPv6 vRouter capability to any VM and allows for any 3rd-party solution, e.g. IPv6 vRouter VNF, as an alternative of Neutron Router or ODL Router, which allows for open innovation.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The audience is anyone who is interested in learning how to best leverage IPv6 capability in OpenStack environment, especially when OpenStack is integrated with other SDN Controllers in real-world deployment. Attendees can expect a detailed review of gap analysis of use case with OpenStack and Open Daylight, and how to configure this novel use case to use a service VM as an IPv6 vRouter, its related user stories, and business scenarios enabled by IPv6 platform, current state and expectation of evolution to address the challenges.

videos.name: Using a Service VM as an IPv6 vRouter

schedule.title: Documentation: Work session
Swift: Work session
The Cloud Infrastructure for Microbial Bioinformatics; Breaking Biological Silos Using OpenStack
schedule.description: Since the first bacterial genome was published 20 years ago, there has been an explosion in the production of sequence data, fuelled by next-generation sequencing, catupulting biology to the forefront of data-driven science. As a consequence, there is now huge demand for the physical infrastructure to produce, analyse and share software and datasets. The CLoud Infrastructure for Microbial Bioinformatics (CLIMB) is a national e-infrastructure, distributed over 4 sites, that uses OpenStack to provide bioinformatics infrastructure as a service to the UK microbiological community. The development of this cutting edge cloud infrastructure has been technically challenging, and here we provide an in depth case study encompassing the design and implementation of our system over the last 18 months; highlighting key pitfalls – and solutions – that are of relevance to anyone who is interested in commissioning or implementing a cloud infrastructure of their own.
schedule.problem_addressed:
This will be a case study, focused on our experience of can designing and delivering bioinformatics infrastructure as a service to enable better data sharing and reproducibility of bioinformatics research.The presentation will articulate many of the key problems that currently face most biological researchersaround

  • Processing
  • Analysing
  • Storing
  • and Sharing

genomic data. Despite considerable investments in training, most biologists remain computational novices with who are often unable or unwilling to use local HPC resources or the command line. The CLoud Infrastructure for Microbial Bioinformatics was designed to overcome this issue; using OpenStack and Ceph to provide a single environment where researchers with a wide spectrum of skills - from complete novice up to experienced developer - can analyse, store and share genome scale datasets at scale.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The session will cover a case study of the implementation of a single OpenStack system, comprised of hardware that is distributed across 4 separate research organisations in the UK.

The session will introduce some of the existing problems that are faced by genome biologists who work on research questions focused around bacterial pathogens, before moving on to outline how Openstack/Cloud has computing has the potential to empower biological researchers, and enable better data sharing and bioinformatics reproducibility.

The attendees will then be introduced to the CLIMB system, with some of our experiences around the implementation and operation of the system.

The attendees should leave with

  • An understanding of several of the key challenges for researchers and for those who support data intensive biology
  • How we have adressed these specifically within CLIMB
  • An overview of some of the major pitfalls that we have encountered implementing our system

videos.name: The Cloud Infrastructure for Microbial Bioinformatics; Breaking Biological Silos Using OpenStack

schedule.title: Oslo: Work session
Kolla: Work session
Big Data Rapid Prototyping by Using Magnum with Cinder and Manila
schedule.description:
Developers have unique challenges when trying to test against large datasets. Traditionally, the cost and time associated with copying and storing large amounts (multiple terabytes) of data has been prohibitive, leading to test and development being done with synthetic data at best. Within the DevOps model for building applications having full sets of real application data to test against is crucial at all stages of an application’s lifecycle. Imagine being able to run 1000’s of tests against replicas of entire multi-TB production datasets, enabling previously unattainable levels of reliability and allowing for an accelerated cadence of application development.  

We will discuss techniques for presenting multiple full datasets to developers within a containerized environment for both ephemeral and persistent use cases, leveraging Manila within an OpenStack environment.
schedule.problem_addressed: We want to allow developers to have access to complete multi-TB datasets for any level of application development and testing. We will show how this is possible within nearly any environment via Magnum with Cinder and Manila.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How a large dataset (multi-TB) can be presented to a containerized application and rapidly replicated for many different use cases.

videos.name: Big Data Rapid Prototyping by Using Magnum with Cinder and Manila

schedule.title: OpenStackAnsible: Work session
Nova: Cross-project with Cinder
Glance: Work session
Magnum: Container Storage - Support for Container Data Volumes
Barbican: Work session
Heat: Continous observer
Mistral: Work session
Manila: Share Groups
Trove: Making it easier to build Trove guest images
Infrastructure: OpenID/SSO for Community Systems
Chef OpenStack: Living the dream: refactoring and still going to production
Ironic: Work session
Enforcing Application SLAs with Congress and Monasca
schedule.description:
Now you got baremetal servers, virtual machines and even containers but an application developer has to know a lot about infrastructure specifics to meet his application SLAs. It actually become worst since now you (as a developer) must know about VM flavors, anti-affinity rules, servers specifications (e.g. spinning disks vs. SSD) and availability zones … Wasn’t it better when someone was taking care of this and you could focus on developing your application? No worries, it will take some work, but there is light at the end of the tunnel.

Application SLAs define the expected behavior of the infrastructure to provide capabilities needed for the application to deliver value in the planned/expected fashion. These SLAs can be defined as a set of complex policies that identify conditions to be met in the infrastructure, these can be as simple as memory availability to complex one based on historical data or patterns.
schedule.problem_addressed: We are going to extend OpenStack Congress to handle the definition of Application Policies so we can simplify the developer/product owner task. For instance we can simply write that the application need to scale to address increasing requests until a certain budget is met, this is then translated in a set of policies that are defining the number of VMs (or containers) and their relative flavors.The second aspect is enforcing those SLAs, and in order to accomplish that, we are going to leverage OpenStack Monasca as a Monitoring and Alarming component. Monasca handles threshold alarms and it can notify a listener via Webhooks. Basically the SLA Policies in Congress are converted in a set of Alarms and sub-Alarms and whenever these are triggered Congress can relate them back to the Policy and re-evaluate it.We are planning to illustrate the approach in detail and provide a short demo of what can be achieved.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn how application developers and product owners can specify high level SLA policies that control how the infrastructure behave to satisfy the application needs.

The monitoring infrastructure will provide real time data to constantly evaluate that the SLAs are met and the overall application health is maintained.

They will also understand relationship between policies and metrics and how these can be transformed into simple threadshold alarms that combined can identify and/or prevent issues in the underlining infrastructure.

videos.name: Enforcing Application SLAs with Congress and Monasca

schedule.title: Marketing Community Meeting
schedule.description:
Join your colleagues in the OpenStack marketing community to evaluate our past projects and plan for future success. This is a roll-up-your-sleeves, conversation-oriented session. We’ll cover:

- 2016 content and campaigns performance 
- High-level messaging for 2016, including how themes emerge in user stories and content 
- Key marketing goals for the remainder of 2016 
- Marketing projects/deliverables for new content and campaigns: what would you recommend, how can you contribute, and how can you leverage it in your business? 
- Promoting your success stories, news and user stories 
- Superuser is evolving: in awards, a magazine and TV. Find out and recommend what’s next.

We encourage you to be part of this conversation and help shape our major projects in the year ahead.

schedule.title: Optimizing Software-Defined Storage for OpenStack
schedule.description: Engineered systems have been met with tremendous market success supporting legacy applications and workloads because build your own hasn’t worked. Why don’t we have similar solutions for new modern cloud applications and workloads? Rolling your own open source solution won’t be for everyone. Likewise, other organizations are looking to integrate OpenStack to existing systems with a sunk cost. Roll your own, pre-packaged distributions, or turnkey appliance – why do folks choose one option instead or another? Why not focus on application development, and leave the infrastructure to someone else? Let's look at use cases and provide some handy tools for your own evaluation.
schedule.problem_addressed: DIY is not for everyone, even though it is extremely desirable. Most organizations do not have the expertise, resources, and time to invest in DIY, so turnkey, integrated appliances are attractive. However, there are many options, so it’s critical for organizations to understand the choices available to them.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: We will take a deep-dive look architectural look at ScaleIO as a standalone software product, an integrated appliance, and as an integrated software option in OpenStackDistributions and discuss how our partnership with Mirantis facilitates these options.

videos.name: Optimizing Software-Defined Storage for OpenStack

schedule.title: Cephfs in Jewel: Stable at Last
schedule.description: The Ceph upstream community is declaring CephFS stable for the first time in the recent Jewel release, but that declaration comes with caveats: while we have filesystem repair tools and a horizontally scalable POSIX filesystem, we have default-disabled exciting features like horizontally-scalable metadata servers and snapshots. This talk will present exactly what features you can expect to see, what's blocking the inclusion of other features, and what you as a user can expect and can contribute by deploying or testing CephFS.
schedule.problem_addressed: Cloud providers are looking to provide easily-scalable file system services. CephFS is preparing to fill this space, just as RBD made easily-scalable block devices easy. Providers will learn about the status of a newly-stable open-source distributed storage system that runs on the same platform (and with the same toolchain) a plurality of them are already using to provide block devices and images to their VMs.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn why they should (or shouldn’t!) choose CephFS to provide file system services to their users. They’ll learn what features are available and what ones are on the roadmap for their future planning.

videos.name: Cephfs in Jewel: Stable at Last

schedule.title: SNAT High Availability Service in Neutron for Distributed Virtual Routers
schedule.description: L3 high availability was introduced in Neutron during the Juno cycle. L3 high availability in Neutron provides a reliable L3 connectivity without losing the agent scalability. High Availability of L3 agent will ensure there will be very little downtime between external and internal networks connectivity.With the introduction of Distributed Virtual Routers the routers are now distributed across the compute Nodes for scalability and high availability is achieved through distributed routers. Even though DVR has distributed the routers and the DNAT functionality, the SNAT functionality is still handled in the Networking Node, which again brings in the requirement for a high availability solution for SNAT.In order to address this issue, Distributed Router SNAT High Availability work was pursued during the Kilo and was completed in Mitaka cycle. This talk will provide an overview of the L3 HA, provide details of the DVR SNAT HA scheduler, config options with respect to legacy and dvr routers
schedule.problem_addressed:
Today Neutron supports DVR and Legacy router implementation for L3 network routing. While legacy routers already support L3 HA for routers in Network node, DVR did not have any support for L3 HA, since the routers are already distributed. Even the routing function for DVR is distributed, its SNAT functionality is still centralized and goes through the Network node in order to address the legacy VPN solution.

Now since the SNAT is centralized we need to provide a High availability solution for SNAT since it becomes a single point of failure.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees of this session will be able to learn about the legacy L3 HA support, the DVR SNAT HA support, configuration options and the pros-cons of L3 HA and DVR SNAT HA combo with Neutron.

videos.name: SNAT High Availability Service in Neutron for Distributed Virtual Routers

schedule.title: Magnum or Murano? OpenStack Options for Container Environment Creation and Management
schedule.description:
OpenStack users who want to create and manage container environments (e.g., Kubernetes, Docker Swarm, Apache Mesos, etc.) can do so with methods native to each solution’s ecology. They can explore OpenStack Magnum’s API, which enables creation of Kubernetes, Swarm or Mesos environments, plus abstract management of container workloads. Or they can use Murano, the application catalog, which deploys Kubernetes clusters, pods, and container applications with Wizard ease.

Which to choose? This session will describe:

  • Magnum and Murano: Intentions, features, workflow
  • Trade-offs in control vs. convenience, and their significance

...And discuss the state of current work aimed at making Magnum deployable and callable by Murano, making Magnum more accessible to less-technical users, and broadening the suite of container solutions Murano can catalog and deploy. Attendees will leave this session with better understanding of options for container-environment deployment within OpenStack.
schedule.problem_addressed: Deploying container environments and managing containerized applications on OpenStack can be challenging, and OpenStack projects that can help — Magnum and Murano — are not yet widely understood or clearly differentiated for users. We hope to inform, disambiguate, and offer users a range of options for deploying and managing container clusters and apps, along with solid understanding of the trade-offs each approach imposes.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Magnum and Murano: Intentions, features, workflow
  • Trade-offs in control vs. convenience, and their significance
  • Magnum and Murano interoperability: status and plans
  • Demo: Deploying Kubernetes cluster with each platform

videos.name: Magnum or Murano? OpenStack Options for Container Environment Creation and Management

schedule.title: Inner Sourcing Expedition - Wipro's Story
schedule.description:
This paper is about Wipro’s journey of creating a community of Open Source enthusiasts across its divisions. Our vision of having 10,000 open source developers across the length and breadth of technologies and is becoming real by following a community based competency development approach.  We call this our “inner sourcing expedition”.

We have enabled the employees to collaborate and learn thru doing using community projects within our organization. The paper would talk about the vision, challenges we faced and our solution and current status of our internal open source community. Our solution addresses behavior change, technology enablement and a gamified reward framework.

Currently we have around 10,000 employees who are part of the opensource community within Wipro and learning and growing together and creating solutions. We would like to share our learning and encourage other enterprises to take an inner sourcing journey and gain benefits.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Wipro has a proven track record of project execution across infrastructure, cloud, applications, data and also hardware. Our expertise is traditionally in custom delivering solutions and vendor supported platforms. We have a developer base of over 75,000 who are mainly users of the technology that we support.

Our vision - to create 10,000 open source developers who are skilled in open source technologies and mentor and nurture their skills and encourage them to contribute to open source projects.

Our challenge was to create a motivating value proposition for people to get into open source world and to change their ways of working.  Reasonably successful employees were reluctant to start in a new technology and that too in a collaborative learning environment.

We had to address multiple facets of organization change management while marching towards the vision along with the technology and motivational challenges
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This session gives a testimony of how people of varied skills, experience and interest and technology background can be identified, mentored and nurtured to form a community with common goals. Gives details of ideas to motivate individuals, different engagement styles and inclusive gamification for a thriving community to function.

It can also serve as an example of how a small team and innovative platform can impact an organization culture and create disruptive growth models.

Session also details the different aspects of community building – an audacious goal, executive commitment, vision and strategy and execution plan.

Session touches upon the implementation details of technology platform, engagement models, individual behavior and its challenges and rewards and gamification.

videos.name: Inner Sourcing Expedition - Wipro's Story

schedule.title: A Deep Dive into Project Astara
schedule.description: Project Astara provides an open source network orchestration platform and is one of the latest members of the OpenStack Big Tent.  In this session, we'll dive into Astara's architecture to explore how the OpenStack ecosystem shaped Astara into a scalable solution.  After of tour of Astara's internals, we will examine how Astara's intergration with Neutron and the other OpenStack services helps to deploy a 100% open source production ready system compatible with a number of open source L2 providers.  We will close with a look at Astara's newest feature, over-the-top orchestration of L3+ services.  Over-the-top services are configured using a standard Neutron installation and enable operators to support a pluggable network service infrastructure allowing users to bring their own network functions to OpenStack.
schedule.problem_addressed: In this session, we will be discussing how the technical internals of Astara and how they integrate with the other OpenStack components such as Neutron to help deployers deliver easily scalable deployments.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will learn in the internal architecture of Astara and how Astara integrates with Neutron by providing backing implementations for Neutron's API.  Knowledge of Astara's architecture will also inform the decisions made by operators when deploying OpenStack.

videos.name: A Deep Dive into Project Astara

schedule.title: Building a Cloud for VNFs & IOT
schedule.description: We’ve been hearing a lot about the use of Network Function Virtualization (NFV) for delivering virtual network functions in a cloud. We take you through all the lessons learned on choosing the right hardware layout and supported featured related to performance and stability with regards to OpenStack and Data Plane Development Kit (DPDK). We’ll talk through the advantages of DPDK, Non Uniform Memory Access (NUMA), and Hugepages, some of the lessons learned and the next steps leveraging DPDK 2.2 and OVS 2.5 to allow jumbo frames and multicast. We'll also cover the mechanism on how to use the same environment for IOT workloads when it comes to high density VMs per compute node.
schedule.problem_addressed: How to solve capacity problems by enabling higher density VMs per server with the rigth hardware.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will walk away from this session with solid knowledge of what hardware should be used and in what way for a high performance OpenStack cloud.

videos.name: Building a Cloud for VNFs & IOT

schedule.title: Intro to OpenStack Magnum with Kubernetes
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

Curious about OpenStack Magnum? This will be a place to learn the basics and get to run some Docker based apps. No prior knowledge of using Magnum, Docker, or Kubernetes is required, however it would be great if you would know some basics of what containers are and know how to use shell.

In this session you will learn how to configure OpenStack Magnum, how to manage VM clusters (Bays) which can host containers (Docker for now), and how to connect to container orchestration tools (we will use Kubernetes) to manage containers. We will go through what is supported by Magnum and what is on the way.

After we are done you will have a much better understanding of what Magnum's role is in the OpenStack and container world, how to operate Magnum CLI, and how you might employ it for your application.

_________________________________________________

Please bring your laptop with at least 6GB of free RAM and at least 2 core i5 CPU. In theory, any OS will work. Also, to save a lot of time for you and others (we won’t have enough USB sticks for everybody):

1. Install Vagrant: https://www.vagrantup.com/downloads.html 

2. Install Virtualbox https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads 

3. And download all files from: https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0BzIDQZTTwQBxM0pqRlBCZE80Q2c&usp=sharing
schedule.problem_addressed: This hands-on session is targeting IT admins who want to get familiar with OpenStack Magnum, particularly how it can simplify deployment of Docker based Kubernetes application on OpenStack Cloud. Participants will be presented simple use case: using Magnum to provision infrastructure for Docker application deployment, running and managing Docker/Kubernetes based containerized web application.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn:

* Overall OpenStack Magnum architecture and features

* Install and configure OpenStack Magnum

* Use OpenStack and particularly Magnum CLI

* Create different bay templates and instantiate bays

* Run Docker container in a bay and use Kubernetes to manage them.

* Scale bays and pods

videos.name: Intro to OpenStack Magnum with Kubernetes

schedule.title: Writing an AngularJS Plugin for Horizon
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

AngularJS is a front-end web framework. It is a popular choice among many web developers for its simple, but powerful features. Horizon has been on the strategic path of “Angularizing” its front-end. Many new Horizon plugins are being created using the Angular library. This workshop is focused on learning how to write an Angular plugin that integrates with the Horizon dashboard.

This workshop will first introduce the basics of writing an Angular plugin for Horizon. We will use the existing Angular LBaaS v2 plugin as an example project to work with and learn from.

Expect a great learning experience for new developers looking to write Horizon Angular plugins as well as experienced Horizon developers to better understand the Angular technology.
schedule.problem_addressed: When using LBaaS v2 support in the community, you have to use the CLI or APIs for the corresponding operations. This session will cover the use case for using Horizon to perform LBaaS v2 key functionality that was recently made available in the community.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Expect a great learning experience for using Horizon to use the LBaaS v2 capabilities, we will also touch on the resource hierarchy. We will cover any gotchas and tips along the way that you should keep in mind while working with this plugin.

videos.name: Writing an AngularJS Plugin for Horizon

schedule.title: Network  Slice Orchestration for 5G Networks
schedule.description: vBrownBag

schedule.title: Wanclouds - CHAI - Looking for Needle in a Haystack
schedule.description: In this session we are going to cover quick diagnosis of issues with Openstack deployments, Services Assurance, and Config compliance. Our goal is to simplify the life when operating openstack and bring dramatic efficiency into the current process.

videos.name: Wanclouds - CHAI - Looking for Needle in a Haystack

schedule.title: Cloud Messaging State of the Union
schedule.description: vBrownBag

schedule.title: Attivo Networks - Who is lurking in your (open) stack?
schedule.description:
As more organizations embrace cloud technologies, there has been an increase in attackers targeting cloud deployments. Cyber attackers aggressively pursue crown jewels in a cloud through lateral movement using privileged escalations. On an average it takes more than 4 months to detect an attack. Attack containment and impact estimation are challenging tasks with increasingly complex cloud deployments. Conventional security products can no more keep up with the threat landscape. Organizations must take an offensive stance to security and they ought to be “on-the-hunt” to ensure they are protected. 

 

In this talk we present how Attivo BOTsink solution detects and contains an attacker who has managed to compromise the weakest link in your OpenStack cloud. We will cover some of the key topics including:

 

- Learn how a non intrusive solution can go a long way in protection against cyber attacks

- Learn to use deception to detect an intruder inside your data center or OpenStack cloud

- Learn how to use Attivo BOTsink to contain and neutralize an attack in OpenStack deployment

videos.name: Attivo Networks - Who is lurking in your (open) stack?

schedule.title: Keystone: Work session
Fuel: Work session
Congress in NFV-based Mobile Cellular Network Fault Recovery
schedule.description:
High service availability is an integral part in mobile core network. As each core node hosts few hundred thousand subscriber sessions, a sub-second level fast recovery is necessary not only to ensure seamless connectivity to the customers, but also to avoid the consequent ‘attach’ storm where all disconnected mobile devices try to reconnect to the mobile network simultaneously, creating control traffic beyond what a node can handle. In NFV-based networks, recovery actions will be performed by a node manager which cannot directly detect virtualized network infrastructure level failures. Therefore, OpenStack needs to detect and notify the corresponding node manager of relevant resource failure. An additional requirement is the filtering of the failures, as the definition of failure and the operational policy may differ among Operators.

We’ll introduce a solution using Congress and extended features to meet these telco requirements, as well as PoC developed with OPNFV Doctor Project.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed:
This talk addresses 3 challenges in realizing high service availability in NFV-based telco-systems.

  1. Fast failure notification: Once a failure is detected in an OpenStack-administered network infrastructure, failure recovery needs to be performed in less than a second, including the failure detection phase as well.
  2. Mapping of physical failure to the right logical failure: This is difficult in OpenStack as backend resource controllers and their configurations are different in OpenStack deployments. This mapping is also needed in OpenStack to find out the right node manager of a virtualized node affected by a failure in the physical infrastructure e.g. failure in a physical server machine.
  3. Adaptability of the relevant backend systems and operator policies: As a failure of interest differs according to an operators admin policy and redundancy of deployed components, an input from an infrastructure monitoring tool needs to be carefully analyzed to determine an appropriate failure.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Details use cases and the consequent requirements for failure management in a mobile cellular network, from NFV-based network design, development and deployment experience on OpenStack
  • How Congress can play a vital role in meeting such failure management requirements
  • On-going progress and success story of collaboration among operators, telco-vendors and open source developers in OpenStack and OPNFV

videos.name: Congress in NFV-based Mobile Cellular Network Fault Recovery
