Trove: Work session
Monitoring a Multi-Region Cloud Based on OpenStack: The FIWARE Lab Case Study
schedule.description:
FIWARE Lab is a multi-region federated Cloud, based on OpenStack. Currently it comprises 15 regions spread all over Europe (but with a presence also in LatAm). It offers a capacity of more than 3000 cores, 10 TB RAM, 500 TB disk and is going to be further expanded with the addition of new regions/nodes.

By leveraging Ceilometer and Monasca, we developed a distributed and scalable monitoring system for FIWARE Lab able to collect, process, analyse and finally present the relevant data to the interested users. This presentation will focus on the architecture of the solution and on how two OpenStack projects have been customized, enhanced and deployed in order to meet the expected requirements: collection of custom resource metrics and sanity check measurements, data confidentiality and data replication, real time data vs historical aggregated data on different dimensions (time, tenant, “space”), data analytics, unified cross-region data visualization. Finally a short demo is presented.
schedule.problem_addressed:
FIWARE Lab is the experimentation platform - based on OpenStack - where FIWARE services can be deployed; FIWARE is an ecosystem that offers standards for IoT-enabled smart applications, integrating technologies for context information gathering, management, publication, real-time processing and big data analysis (i.e. FIWARE brings on top of OpenStack an IoT platform cloud services).

Different stakeholders are animating FIWARE Lab with different needs and different profiles in terms of monitoring requirements spawning from accessing single resource metrics to having an aggregated view of the status of all the regions, from keeping data private on a given (geographical) region to sharing data among all the regions, from managing real time data to requesting intensive data analytics. All these challenges (and many more) have been tackled during the development of the FIWARE Lab monitoring system.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The presentation offers a case study for the monitoring of a multi-region and federated Cloud. Attendees will learn how to set up a distributed and scalable architecture, based on Ceilometer and Monasca, that offers real-time monitoring, data aggregation, data confidentiality, data analytics and sanity check measurement:

- Cloud providers will get a fresh perspective on how to manage the monitoring of a federated multi-region Cloud and how to solve issues that they can face;

- Developers will get a deep dive into architectural patterns and deployment solutions for multi-region and federated Cloud monitoring.

videos.name: Monitoring a Multi-Region Cloud Based on OpenStack: The FIWARE Lab Case Study

QA: DefCore and Interoperability Testing
schedule.description:
The DefCore Working Group is formalizing the requirements for what an interoperable test is. With the successful history of collaboration between the QA and DefCore teams, this working session is targeted towards building that relationship and planning for working on short and long term test issues.

This includes identifying work items for currently flagged tests, planning for the refactoring of existing tests to meet DefCore test requirements (including removing unnecessary admin privileges where possible), and long term planning for the augmentation of existing tests and creation of new tests for verifying cloud interoperability."

Multi-unit OpenStack Cloud Deployment Using LXD Containers On Your Laptop
schedule.description: Testing OpenStack deployments without having access to multiple pieces of physical server infrastructure can be challenging;  Find out how to use LXD (the container hypervisor for Linux) with Juju (the service modelling tool from Canonical) to deploy OpenStack in LXC containers on your laptop, simulating a real world multi-node deployment with Open vSwitch overlay networking and running KVM instances without the overhead of nested virtualization.
schedule.problem_addressed: Testing and validating OpenStack software and deployment topologies without the requirement for multiple physical servers.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: How to deploy OpenStack in containers on their laptop.

videos.name: Multi-unit OpenStack Cloud Deployment Using LXD Containers On Your Laptop

schedule.title: Gender-Diversity Analysis of Technical Contributions in The OpenStack Projects
schedule.description:
Women are half of the population in the world, but they are still under represented in the tech world industry nowadays. While there are clear actions in favor of attracting more female developers in order to bring more diversity to the project, the OpenStack Foundation shows a similar trend with this respect.

Some numbers can be easily extracted from the Women of OpenStack group in Linkedin with more than 600 members and 137 discussion. Specific diversity-focused panels during the summits. Women of OpenStack mailing list with close 380 emails in 2015 and 90 different people commenting and changing ideas [own analysis].

This talk will cover the journey of the OpenStack ecosystem gender diversity since it was born till nowadays. This will focus on the analysis of the code review and code development activity. It is intended to be a quantitative analysis plus specific manual polishing process to help in the accuracy of the data.
schedule.problem_addressed:
This analysis is focused on addressing the issue of having actual numbers about technical contributions to the OpenStack repositories by groups of people that may be under represented. This analysis is specifically focused on female contributions to the Git and Gerrit repositories of the OpenStack Foundation.

Analyzing the evolution of the gender-gap through the history of OpenStack may help to better understand among other things if the policies applied by the Foundation or specific working groups are taking effect with this respect.

Having diverse groups of people participating in the same project enrich this and help to address issues from several perspectives. This study aims at understanding with numbers the current situation of several processes at the level of development.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
This talk will provide insights about the current situation of the gender-gap in the OpenStack at the development level. This new perspective is expected to enrich the current set of facts about women in OpenStack.

The audience is expected to understand the evolution of the gender-diversity of the OpenStack projects since its conception until nowadays. As this is mainly focused on the analysis of Git and Gerrit repositories, this talk will open further paths of analysis for those interested in this type of analysis.

videos.name: Gender-Diversity Analysis of Technical Contributions in The OpenStack Projects

schedule.title: Multisite OpenStack for NFV: Bridging the Gap
schedule.description:
NFV infrastructure will be distributed across multiple geo-locations, to place workload close to the end user for better user experience, and introduce some cross -site requirements like service chaining, high availability and disaster recovery. There are gaps in OpenStack in such geo-distributed clouds such as: 

  • Support VNF high availability across OpenStack 
  • Support Multisite VNF geo site-disaster recovery 
  • Single unified view for operators 
  • Multi-site quota management 
  • Sync tenant resources like images, ssh-keys, security groups 
  • Policy driven VNF placements 
  • Optimized resource utilization 
  • Dynamic Service Functions Chaining across sites 

Several projects like OPNFV Multisite, Tacker, Kingbird and Tricircle projects have collaborated to address the requirements for NFV. In this session, come learn about: 

  1. Need for multisite in NFV 
  2. Gaps in OpenStack 
  3. Existing projects and solutions 
  4. Gaps in these solutions and what different teams are doing to fix it

 The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: Operators manage several OpenStack versions running in their infrastructure and need a way to reduce the complexity inherent in multisite cloud deployments. Also, the OPNFV architecture requires NFVO component to interact with the VIM layer to aggregate NFVI resources and provide intelligent VIM selections which is currently unaddressed in OpenStack NFV realm.  Last but not least, multi-site deployed OpenStack should be able to provide a unified view for NFV Orchestrators or directly for the operator to consume.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will be able to understand the challenges in multisite NFV orchestration and learn how Tacker NFVO component working alongside projects like Tricircle and Kingbird provides a solution through a unified view of resource management.

videos.name: Multisite OpenStack for NFV: Bridging the Gap

schedule.title: Swift 102: Beyond CRUD - More Real Demos
schedule.description:
OpenStack Swift was designed to allow application developers to focus on their apps without worrying about how the storage operates underneath. Swift takes care of durability, concurrency, and availability of data, and it provides a suite of accessible features that give application developers the tools they need to focus on making their applications awesome.

In this updated session, SwiftStack's developer and ISV program manager will cover extended features of the Swift API and provide tips and sample code on how your application can best use Swift to provide high-performance access to your data. For devs that prefer the S3 API, this session will show how that API can also be used with Swift. If your applications use Swift today or may use it tomorrow, you will benefit from advice on what works best and getting the most from Swift.
schedule.problem_addressed: Many developers may know the basics of create, read, update and delete, but may not know about other features and operations that can improve how their applications use Swift object storage. The Swift API is more powerful than other object storage APIs, and capabilities are available to developers. The sample code discussed in the session provides ideas on several use cases for Swift, e.g. replacing underlying storage volumes. Swift can be extended by middleware.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This session is for Developers and DevOps engineers in OpenStack environments. It is an intermediate session, but can also be followed by beginners.

videos.name: Swift 102: Beyond CRUD - More Real Demos

schedule.title: Big Data BBQ: Dining at The OpenStack Buffet to Create Cloud Applications
schedule.description:
OpenStack is more than just a collection of services with a great dashboard interface, it is also a platform for building applications that consume and utilize cloud resources. Combine this platform with the power of big data, and you have a recipe for scalable, cloud-aware, data processing applications.

In this talk we will follow a developer’s journey along the path of creating a real-time streaming Spark application on OpenStack, exploring methods for creating cloud applications. We will also demonstrate how to use OpenStack’s Python clients to configure message queues for data ingestion, persistent storage for processed data, and computing nodes for large scale analytics and visualizations.

Attendees should expect to walk away from this session with an understanding of how they can use OpenStack to create, deploy, update, and maintain data processing applications at scale that live entirely in the cloud.
schedule.problem_addressed: Using OpenStack can often just mean spawning virtual machines, or interacting through the dashboard. But, there is a large range of possibilities when looking at OpenStack from the perspective of an application builder. This talk addresses the problem of creating cloud-aware big data applications that can utilize an OpenStack deployment to empower larger compositions of cloud resources.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees to this presentation should expect to learn how they can use the various OpenStack Python clients to create an application that will deploy a big data Spark application that can utilize cloud resources from a variety of projects (Sahara, Trove, Zaqar, Nova). They should also expect to learn about building applications through the Murano project.

videos.name: Big Data BBQ: Dining at The OpenStack Buffet to Create Cloud Applications

schedule.title: Rocket Fuel for Networks: SDN Solutions with OpenStack Fuel
schedule.description:
Providing secure, high-performance, SLA-compliant cloud services to multiple tenants in multiple locations with hybrid cloud topologies is nearly impossible to do with OpenStack’s default networking back-ends. Juniper Contrail SDN provides a more mature solution, with a logical leaf-spine layout for added performance and resilience and BGP-based federation at the network edges for facilitating hybrid cloud connectivity. But manually integrating it requires complex configuration. The Juniper Contrail Networking plugin for Fuel virtually automates deployment, making it easy to add Сontrail SDN as a networking backend option.

The session covers:

  • Juniper Contrail plugin integration
  • How the Fuel Contrail plugin works
  • DPDK with Contrail enablement

Live demo of environment creationAttendees will leave this session with a firm picture of what constitutes a mature SDN solution for OpenStack, with a toolkit for simplified deployment.
schedule.problem_addressed: Manually integrating Juniper Contrail with OpenStack requires relatively complex configuration, local repository creation, multi-node manual deployment of components and careful re-configuration of OpenStack services — dozens of steps. But the Juniper Contrail Networking plugin for Fuel virtually automates deployment, making it easy to add Сontrail SDN for OpenStack as a networking backend option with SR-IOV and DPDK support.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
In this session, we’ll cover:

  • Juniper Contrail plugin integration
  • How the Fuel Contrail plugin works, including:
  • Logical architecture
  • Components
  • Technical solution description
  • DPDK with Contrail enablement

Live demo of environment creationAttendees will leave this session with a firm picture of what constitutes a mature SDN solution for OpenStack, with a toolkit for simplified deployment.

videos.name: Rocket Fuel for Networks: SDN Solutions with OpenStack Fuel

schedule.title: MidoNet Scalability Testing with Neutron and Open Source Tools
schedule.description:
The flexibility of SDNs in contrast to traditional networks that are bounded to hardware restrictions is increasing the need to provide SDN scalability benchmarks such as the maximum number of routers, networks or virtual machines; what is the supported workload or the maximum flow setup rate.

Although SDN is revolutionizing data center networks, its testing, benchmarking and monitoring at scale remains a major challenge which requires the tools capable of handling thousands of resources, such as ports or instances as well as the traffic between them.

This talk presents the scalability tests done for MidoNet with OpenStack Neutron using open source tools. Midonet-sandbox uses Docker containers to automate the deployment of the infrastructure under test, OpenStack Rally runs first OpenStack Tempest for sanity checks then Neutron tasks for addressing scalability benchmark tests while monitoring different metrics such as virtual topology objects count with InfluxDB, Telegraf and Grafana.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Companies adopting OpenStack should be able to know the performance and limitations of the network virtualization solutions available before deciding the SLAs they can offer to their customers.

This performance and limitations include networking scalability and workload benchmarks, moreover taking into account that massive scalability is one the OpenStack Open Source Cloud Mission.

However, providing these results remains a challenge that the set of open source tools presented in this session is addressing.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this session we will present the practices used at Midokura for network scalability, benchmarking and monitoring tests performed on MidoNet with Neutron using a set of open source tools such as Midonet-sandbox, OpenStack Rally, OpenStack Tempest, InfluxDB, Telegraf and Grafana.

videos.name: MidoNet Scalability Testing with Neutron and Open Source Tools

schedule.title: Realize SFC Using ONOS Controller
schedule.description:
SDN moves management functions out of the hardware and places it in controller software that executes in a server. As a result, entire service chains can be provisioned and constantly reconfigured from the controller. Communication service providers and public cloud providers carry such a wide variety of data types and applications, Hence SDN and NFV-driven service chaining can improve their business models just by simplifying the service chain provisioning process.

This presentation will talk about how one can realize service function chaining (using networking-sfc) using ONOS controller by guiding attendees

* Through ONOS ML2 plugin architecture.

* How ONOS manages OpenStack network functionality.

* How ONOS realizes SFC followed by a demo.
schedule.problem_addressed:
[1] Overview on OpenStack Neutron Modular plugin architecture.

[2] How to integrate Neutron and ONOS controller.

[3] How ONOS controllers realize SFC using the defined networking-sfc NBI 's.

[4] Demonstrate networking-sfc and ONOS integration.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
[1] About Neutron Plugin.

[2] How neutron can integrate with ONOS controllers.

[3] Understanding ONOS ML2 and SFC architecture.

[4] Demo to understand the explained concepts.

[5] Current ONOS SFC Project Status: Where are we now and what's next ;)

videos.name: Realize SFC Using ONOS Controller

schedule.title: Chinac - Engineering Practice of OpenStack in Cloud Service
schedule.description:
Chinac is one of the leading cloud service providers in China. It has been providing both public cloud and private cloud services since 2010. As OpenStack has been the factual standard of open source cloud, in the past three years, Chinac has gradually migrate our cloud services to be openstack-based. That includes our private cloud brand CloudUltra and part of our public cloud.

In this session, Zheng Jun(CTO of Chinac) will share with you about the engineering practice of how to build production-level cloud services around OpenStack in Chinac. It will also include the extensions and optimizations Chinac explored to meet the client needs.

OW2 - AppHub, the new OpenStack friendly open-source marketplace, vendor-neutral and quality oriented
schedule.description: AppHub is a factory and a marketplace allowing open-source software vendors to easily publish software assets for seamless deployment to any OpenStack infrastructure, and ISV consumers to discover and install trustworthy software in the Cloud. The presentation will cover how AppHub eases the continuous configuration and deployment of enterprise applications and how it helps vendors reach out to the market. A live demonstration of the platform, from asset cataloguing to packaging, advertising and deploying, will cover the benefits of AppHub for OSS producers, OpenStack users and Cloud providers. AppHub is a project bringing together OW2, UShareSoft and Fraunhofer Fokus. AppHub is supported by the European Commission.

Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). schedule.title: Keystone: Work session
Heat: Work session
Manila: Work session
Fuel: Work session
Sahara: Work session
Enhanced Platform Aware Deployment of VNFs
schedule.description:
Cloud data centers today  are beginning to use COTS hardware that comprise platforms with a variety of technologies that offer some basic computing functions as well as performance and higher efficiency functions.With the advent of NFV, network services that used to be deployed on proprietary costly hardware are now deployable quickly and flexibly on COTS hardware platforms. The higher performance obtained using dedicated proprietary hardware can also be achieved in a NFV platform (comprised from COTS) by configuring and/or fine tuning the platform capabilities such as SR-IOV, CPU Pinning, Huge Pages and NUMA topology. In this session, we will discuss how the above mentioned performance parameters could be specified as a requirement per Virtualized Network Function (VNF) and have the Tacker NFV Orchestrator ensure that the VNF  is placed on the optimal NFV platform that meets the specified performance requirements.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed: Heat, or murano is the application orchestrator, while Tacker is the NVF orchestator. How to place a VNF on an efficient and high performance aware platform is a challenging task. This session addresses the use case of placing a Virtualized Network Function on a NFV OpenStack that delivers performance comparable to dedicated hardware appliance.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
The attendees will walk away with:

  • An overview/understanding of how SR-IOV, CPU Pinning, NUMA Topology and Huge Pages can help a VNF placed on NFV platforms obtain performance that is comparable to a dedicated hardware appliance
  • How to specify performance requirement configurations for a VNF in Tacker VNFD Templates

videos.name: Enhanced Platform Aware Deployment of VNFs

schedule.title: Kolla: Work session
Trove: Work session
Nova: Unconference #2
Dragonflow: Work session
How Burton Snowboards Is Carving Down the OpenStack Trail
schedule.description:
Enterprise IT is under pressure to store and protect more data than ever before, but budgets are not growing at the same rate. For cost reasons alone, scaling out a traditional SAN or NAS was not an answer. We @ Burton looked for alternatives, and while we did not have cloud applications, we found that we could use OpenStack as a starting project for getting into OpenStack, and specifically Swift for storing Commvault backups.

This session will share how Burton discovered OpenStack object storage as a solution, and the criteria that went into choosing to deploy it for both immediate and future needs. Part of the sharing includes how we have utilized our private cloud after the initial deployment. Like Burton, you may also have applications running in your environment that already support object storage APIs like Swift and S3.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack Swift has many of the fundamentals businesses desire when for their first private storage cloud, but those businesses cannot allocate (or are absent of) the engineering resources necessary to build their own complete storage solution. They also do not know how to cross the chasm of where they are today with traditional storage to where they want to be with cloud storage.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This session is for anyone who desires to reduce storage cost for lower-tier applications like backup and want and want to eliminate some inherent barriers of their storage infrastructure, while establishing a foundation for additional work on OpenStack.

videos.name: How Burton Snowboards Is Carving Down the OpenStack Trail

Turn up the Heat with LBaaS v2
schedule.description:
This presentation will start by introducing basic concepts in using Heat with Load Balancer As A Service (LBaaS) v2. Have you been wondering whether to use LBaaS v1 or LBaaS v2 especially if you are using Heat? This session will help you get a good understanding of the advantages of LBaaS v2 and some of the reasons on why you should not mix and match LBaaS v1 and LBaaS v2.

We will cover fundamental differences between LBaaS v1 and LBaaS v2 from a Heat perspective; discuss the Heat resource hierarchy and dive into the depths of the resource properties and attributes.

Want to see it in action? We will make the learning practical by showing Heat template examples for LBaaS v2.
schedule.problem_addressed: Auto scaling is becoming more and more important and LBaaS plays a big role in that. LBaaS v1 and v2 are the two API versions available in the OpenStack community. If you are using orchestration in your environment, you will learn about the v2 support in Heat and understand the considerations on whether to go with LBaaS v1 vs LBaaS v2.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
We will cover fundamental differences between LBaaS v1 and LBaaS v2 from a Heat perspective; discuss the Heat resource hierarchy and dive into the depths of the resource properties and attributes.

We will make the learning practical by showing Heat template examples for LBaaS v2.

videos.name: Turn up the Heat with LBaaS v2

schedule.title: Installing, Configuring, and Managing a 300+ OpenStack Node Network In Under An Hour
schedule.description: Deploying and managing a large OpenStack deployment can be daunting, but much easier when you use standard DevOps automation tools, a Linux-based network, and commodity servers and switches. This session details the design and implementation of an L3 network underlay, routing to the host, and a hardware VXLAN gateway used with an enterprise OpenStack distribution on 300+ OpenStack compute nodes.
schedule.problem_addressed:
• Clarify and “de-FUD” practical scalability concerns with OpenStack in general
  • Simplify OpenStack networking with standard linux DevOps tools and white-box commodity switches and servers
  • Utilize network routing to the host using Quagga
  • Ability to simulate any size implementation into virtual instances for planning and POC prior to production deployment
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Understand the different choices and deciding between network topologies (L2 vs. L3)
  • Use DevOps automation tools to scale out all switch configs simultaneously
  • Incorporate white-box network switches into new and existing OpenStack deployments
  • Understand the full bill of materials (BOM) that was used for testing

videos.name: Installing, Configuring, and Managing a 300+ OpenStack Node Network In Under An Hour

schedule.title: I18n Workshop: Translation Processes and Tools
schedule.description:
I18n team is responsible to make OpenStack accessible to people of all language backgrounds. We translate OpenStack dashboard and OpenStack documents into different languages. We have processes to manage translation related activities, e.g. glossary, translation memory, review, translation check and etc. We have tools to support these processes, e.g. use Zanata and automation jobs.

In this session, we want to collect feedback from translators and evaluate the inconveniences of current translation tools and translation processes. We will have translators and tool developers together and discuss about how to improve in the future.

The workshop agenda and discussions will be tracked here: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/austin-i18n-workshop.
schedule.problem_addressed: We will evaluate the inconveniences of current translation tools and translation process, e.g. glossary management process, review process and translation check process. We will discuss about how to improve in the future.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: People who contribute translations to OpenStack can join the session and give the feedback. Translation tool maintainers and developers can discuss the improvements.

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: Write a File, Read as an Object
schedule.description: This session tells about a solution to "objectize" files ingested via file interface like NFS/SMB to make them visible in Swift container listing so they can be accessed via object interface (Openstack Swift). The session begins with a short overview of SwiftOnFile, which is needed to understand the data placement mechanism for unified file and object access. We will then explain the "objectization" process that does synchronization between file metadata and object metadata that ensures accurate container and account listing. This honors Swift semantics of “eventual consistency” where file data gets reflected in object interface eventually. We will also talk about how the file protocol's authorization semantics are honored by preserving the Access Control Lists set on files and directories from file interface.
schedule.problem_addressed:
With increasing popularity of Openstack Swift object storage for storing unstructured data and need for a capability to run big data analytics on it, SwiftOnFile was developed so that object data could be accessed via file interface that advanced analytics systems like MapReduce require. It addresses the use case where data is ingested via object and needs to be accessed via file.

There is also a strong need for the other way multi-protocol access. Legacy devices like cameras, medical and scientific devices, are still based on traditional file access protocols. Data is ingested via such devices as files in a file based storage. It would be best to share and access this data over cloud using HTTP REST based object interface. The current SwiftOnFile diskfile solution does not address the case of data ingests via file and access via object.

It also does not ensure retaining of file ownership and access control.Our session addresses these issues.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: With this session the audience would learn how to setup unified file and object access in their Swift deployment. We also give design points and factors to be considered for the objectization process that would enable the listeners to build their own objectization solution around SwiftOnFile deployment. We provide ways to retain ACLs and ownerships across file and object protocols so a truely unified access solution could be build between these two protocols.

videos.name: Write a File, Read as an Object

schedule.title: Policy Canvas: Draw Your Policies for OpenStack Services
schedule.description: We introduce a Policy Canvas which is a highly user-friendly and simple front-end interface to manage policies like drawing diagrams on whiteboard or note. Most administrators and operators draw their policies first in hand and translate them to specific policy languages or commands manually. It is error-prone and requires much time and effort. Our system provides a unified and simple graph drawing tool for specifying policies for multiple OpenStack services. It can automatically translate the graph model to relevant OpenStack services using APIs and commands. In addition, some of the policies can be given by multiple stakeholders such as tenant, cloud operator, system administrator, or application developers. Our system can detect/resolve conflicts as much as possible. In this session, we introduce our Policy Canvas running on Horizon and demonstrate how to create multiple network policies and automatically deploy them to the OpenStack via Congress and Neutron.
schedule.problem_addressed: In OpenStack, there are many network policies for offering governance and compliance for the purpose of security, QoS, SLA, etc. The current front-end service provides to manage all policies using written languages (e.g. Datalog in Congress) or security groups/rules. Congress project has provided a front-end interface for specifying Datalog on Horizon but still not user-friendly. Our Policy Canvas is as easy as possible for most of ordinary users (or experts) to specify policies and check troubleshooting based on their policies. Every user focuses on only their policies without considering conflicts. Our backend engine for Policy Canvas will do resolution of the conflicts and reports to users via GUI. This will be very interesting to most of participants who want to use or specify policies for OpenStack environment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: In this session, we will introduce our Policy Canvas running on OpenStack Horizon and give a demonstration for how to create multiple network policies and automatically deploy them to the OpenStack via Congress and Neutron. Attendees will learn about 1) how to create network policies using our Policy Canvas, 2) how to apply Policy Canvas for multiple OpenStack services, 3) how to deploy created policies to OpenStack via OpenStack Neutron/Congress, and 4) future vision of Policy Canvas for other OpenStack services.

videos.name: Policy Canvas: Draw Your Policies for OpenStack Services

schedule.title: Speeding up Developer Productivity with OpenStack and Open Source Tools
schedule.description:
OpenStack’s orchestration service and APIs enable developers to easily deploy application infrastructure themselves…but what if developers want to use the popular open source tools with which they're already familiar?

This talk covers how developers can use tools from HashiCorp (Vagrant, Terraform, Packer), Docker, Ansible, Puppet, and others to quickly provision workloads on OpenStack clouds. The presenters will share practical examples that attendees can follow along with at the talk and/or take back home to try in their own labs.
schedule.problem_addressed:
This talk addresses the need to empower developers to be successful with using OpenStack clouds. The OpenStack platform provides the capabilities that developers are searching for from other cloud platforms.

Let's demonstrate how developers can be successful with their deployments on OpenStack with the tools that they are already using.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees will learn how to...

  • Use Vagrant, Puppet, Docker Machine, and Ansible to provision resources
  • Use Packer to create images
  • Use Terraform to deploy application infrastructure

videos.name: Speeding up Developer Productivity with OpenStack and Open Source Tools

schedule.title: Neutron Quality of Service, New Features And Future Roadmap.
schedule.description:
Starting at Liberty, the Neutron team introduced the Quality of Service framework, the initial stone to provide quality of service settings on the Neutron networking API.

The initial implementation only supported VM-egress bandwidth policing, addressing the chatty neighbour use case, and letting CSPs provide different levels of network service if they wanted.

In Mitaka, two new features are being introduced:

  • DSCP rules, to mark and prioritize traffic at L3 level.
  • Role based access control for QoS policies, allowing a finer grade of sharing for QoS policies, the administrator would be able to share specific policies with specific tenants, oposed to the previous (share/no share to all the tenants).

Also support has been extended from the OVS and SRIOV agents, to Linux Bridge, while OVN is also considering to implement QoS support too.
schedule.problem_addressed: The Quality of Service framework allows operators to fine tune their network settings to prioritize traffic, avoiding high priority control traffic from starving (for example API requests, rpc messaging, and SSH control sessions), and prioritizing demanding applications where latency of packet loss is an issue (VoIP, video conference).
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees should learn about the newest QoS features that have been introduced to Neutron during this cycle.

videos.name: Neutron Quality of Service, New Features And Future Roadmap.

schedule.title: Integration of Neutron, Nova and Designate: How to Use It and How to Configure It
schedule.description: This presentations will be a hands on demonstration on how to use and configure the integration between Neutron, Nova and Designate.The approach will be highly practical. Attendees will be provided with a VM with DevStack, where they will be able to follow the presentation.
schedule.problem_addressed: The code to integrate Neutron, Nova and Designate was developed and merged during the Liberty and Mitaka cycles. With this accomplished, this presentation intends to spread knowledge to users and administrators on how to use and configure this integration effectively. It will also provide the opportunity to gather direct feedback from users and administrators.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
At the end of this presentation, attendees will be able to explain the following topics:

  • Use cases
  • Alternatives for the external DNS service: Designate (reference implementaion) and Infoblox
  • Publishing Nova instances data in the external DNS service
  • Publishing floating ips and ports data in the external DNS service
  • Configuration of Nova, Neutron and Designate
  • Performance considerations
  • How to write a driver for other DNS services

videos.name: Integration of Neutron, Nova and Designate: How to Use It and How to Configure It

schedule.title: Fostering Full Equality, Organized by the Women of OpenStack
schedule.description:
Following up on the themes related to gender equality presented at the previous Summit talks sponsored by The Women of OpenStack working group, this session will focus on our vision of a world where the OpenStack community is truly and completely blind to meaningless differences in gender, color, creed and culture. What will this new world look like? How will it differ from the current one?

A panel of people from all walks of life will explore what that future is and what we can do as a community as a whole to achieve it.
schedule.problem_addressed: The OpenStack Community is not immune to the outside world. GamerGate, FOSDEM and other recent scandals related to the acceptance of women and other minorities in the technology community amply demonstrate the need for change.  The issues of gender and ethnic bias are just as relevant within the OpenStack community as anywhere else. Raising the awareness for the community is important for maintaining our reputation for inclusivity and fairness in all our relationships.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Suggestions for practices that allow all people regardless of their gender, origin, color or creed to participate fully in the OpenStack Community, including:

  • Be mindful of subtle biases and how they can color people’s judgment
  • Institutionalizing inclusivity to ensure fair treatment for all
  •  Understanding the critical roles of all the people in the OpenStack community, technical and business focused alike.
  • How to be more accepting of alternative ways to contribute

videos.name: Fostering Full Equality, Organized by the Women of OpenStack

schedule.title: Install and Configure OpenStack Octavia
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

In this interactive workshop, members of the Octavia team will walk attendees through the installation and configuration of Octavia, the Open Stack LoadBalancer, on a virtual machine. Attendees will leave with an understanding of the various components of Octavia, how to configure and tune the controller and the amphora.

Attendees will learn: 

  • Octavia Architecture 101
  • How to Install and Configure Octavia
  • How to enable Active-Standby
  • How to perform day to day Octavia operations tasks
  • End user usage of the API, CLI, Horizon UI
  • Tips and Tricks for using Octavia
  • Contributing to Octavia 101
schedule.problem_addressed: Octavia is the operator grade Load Balancer for OpenStack and the M release will contain important new features like Active-Pasive which require some training to be configured correctly. After attending this class users will be able to use the load balancer to it's full potential and potentially building more stable applications.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Octavia Architecture 101
  • How to Install and Configure Octavia
  • How to enable Active-Standby
  • How to perform day to day Octavia operations tasks
  • End user usage of the API, CLI, Horizon UI
  • Tips and Tricks for using Octavia
  • Contributing to Octavia 101

videos.name: Install and Configure OpenStack Octavia

schedule.title: Deploying Application Infrastructure on OpenStack
schedule.description:
RSVP required.

This hands-on workshop aims to introduce a set of tools for automating infrastructure deployment, network troubleshooting, and traffic monitoring on OpenStack clouds. Members of the audience will be provided access to their own dedicated OpenStack environment. We begin by introducing Heat Orchestration Templates, and provisioning a 3-tier app in the OpenStack cloud. This exercise highlights automated network configuration of both virtual and physical network workloads. We then gain hands-on experience with advanced network troubleshooting techniques. The speaker will then guide the audience in the process of deploying monitoring infrastructure. Attendees will be provided free access to online OpenStack labs for an additional three months.
schedule.problem_addressed: Small teams of developers often lack the required resources and/or knowledge to deploy and maintain a CI/CD infrastructure on a private cloud. This workshop is an introduction to a self-serve workflow for automating the deployment of a dev/test/production infrastructure in an OpenStack cloud.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn how to deploy infrastructure for a team of developers in an OpenStack cloud. In addition to compute and storage, firewalls and load balancers will be service chained to provide performance and security. The audience will become acquainted with declarative-style languages for describing infrastructure.

videos.name: Deploying Application Infrastructure on OpenStack

schedule.title: Using A Single Software-Defined Storage Platform for a Multi-Datacenter, Multi-Protocol OpenStack Cloud
schedule.description: vBrownBag

schedule.title: Seamless Deployment into OpenStack with the AppHub Factory
schedule.description: vBrownBag

schedule.title: Certified OpenStack Administrator Exam
schedule.description:
RSVP Required

Be among the first to demonstrate your OpenStack expertise with the new Certified OpenStack Administrator exam offered by the OpenStack Foundation. Testing will take place alongside the workshops and intensive training sessions in the OpenStack Academy building (JW Marriott). Test takers will have a private work station in a small room and will be provided a laptop to take the exam (which is browser-based and will be both live and remotely proctored). The exam is expected to take 2 - 3 hours, and results will be delivered the following week.

The exam is performance-based and will test the baseline skills of an OpenStack Administrator, a person with at least 6 months of OpenStack experience who provides day-to-day operation and management of an OpenStack cloud. Learn more about the specific content areas where test takers will be expected to demonstrate their knowledge: https://www.openstack.org/coa/requirements

schedule.title: Predictive Auto-Scaling for Web Applications
schedule.description: vBrownBag

Watcher, a Resource Manager for OpenStack: Plans for the N-release and Beyond
schedule.description: Watcher is an open source software package which provides a flexible and scalable resource optimization service for multi-tenant OpenStack-based clouds. Watcher provides a complete optimization loop—including everything from a metrics receiver, optimization processor andan action plan applier. This provides a robust framework to realize a wide range of cloud optimization goals, including the reduction of data center operating costs, increased system performance via intelligent virtual machine migration,increased energy efficiency, etc. The overall goal is that OpenStack-based clouds equipped with Watcher will decrease their Total Cost of Ownership by way of more efficient use of their infrastructure through targeted optimizations and close-loop automation. In this talk we will go over the state of Watcher as it is today, its architecture, the team’s accomplishments for the Mitaka release and our plans for the N-release and beyond.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session describes the Watcher architecture and its pluggable framework. The longer term goal of Watcher will be to perform audits and optimize resources to meet specific goals’ SLAs. We expect to use a service like OpenStack Congress if it is ready to provide us with a framework for Policy as a Service across any collection of cloud services. In a Watcher-enabled Cloud the initial placement is not critical since Watcher continuously or at specific times audits the Cloud against a set of optimization algorithms and build recommended action plans. These plans are then carried out automatically or the Cloud administrators can manually perform all or some of the recommendations. In the end the goal of the recommended action plans is to re-arranges or re-allocate the resources using specific actions  (VM migration, turn servers on and off, etc.) to ensure that specific high-level SLAs and goals are met.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: The attendees will learn about Watcher and its role as a Resource Optimization Service which is crucial in optimizing the TCO of the existing OpenStack Clouds. They will learn about the vision we have for Watcher around SLA Risk Mitigation in a Datacenter. We will also go over some existing Watcher optimizaton algorithms that have been ported  to Watcher as part of the Mitaka release as well as our plans with more optimization algorithms moving forward.

videos.name: Watcher, a Resource Manager for OpenStack: Plans for the N-release and Beyond

schedule.title: QA: Newton Priorities
Tacker: Development Track: Newton Feature Pipeline
Telemetry: Work session
FILE This: Swift API, Then S3 API, And Now POSIX Access to OpenStack Swift
schedule.description:
OpenStack developers have had all they need in the Swift API to build new applications and store unstructured data in Swift. But what about classic apps that are not yet refactored? And maybe there are requirements to read from or move data between Swift and NAS storage.

SwiftStack has middleware for Amazon S3 API support, and is working on building support for POSIX interfaces directly into Swift. The Swift PTL, as well as the author of the O'Reilly publication "OpenStack Swift", lead this session and share the exciting developments that will broaden Swift's ability to support more application workloads and store more data.
schedule.problem_addressed: Classic applications as well as bi-modal workloads may not be 100% refactored to support API access, hence file access to data in Swift solves access limits and opens up new use cases. Gateways have been an option in the past, but are suboptimal based on added complexity and cost. With native support for POSIX interfaces, classic apps can benefit from the unified namespace and scalability of Swift directly, and workflows can be supported by Swift regardless of where all parts of the application are in their journey moving to cloud operations.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: This session is for anyone that has basic familiarity of Swift and has interest in learning more about how workloads that require file access can integrate with Swift without the need for a gateway.

videos.name: FILE This: Swift API, Then S3 API, And Now POSIX Access to OpenStack Swift

schedule.title: Networking-Calico, a Routing-Based Implementation of IP-Only Connectivity Between VMs - What, Why, How and the Future
schedule.description: networking-calico is a Neutron driver that provides IP-only connectivity between VMs based on standard IP routing and iptables. It is a new project in the Neutron stadium since last August, but has not yet been fully introduced to the Neutron developer community. This talk will explain what the networking-calico project is, why it is interesting for some OpenStack deployments, and how it works so far. I will also talk about what more is needed for networking-calico to be a first class member of the Neutron project and community, both technically and procedurally; and finish with musing on the relationship between Neutron’s backends and its API, and why it makes sense – at least transiently – to have multiple backends implementing the same API.
schedule.problem_addressed: The problem that networking-calico addresses – at least for some OpenStack deployments, particularly those with workloads that only need IP connectivity – is the complexity and consequent troubleshooting difficulty of networking that is implemented using overlay approaches. The problem in the context of the Neutron developer community is that we haven’t yet presented these points – and hence what networking-calico does – clearly enough and to a broad enough audience. So my aim with this talk is to provide and spread introductory knowledge about what networking-calico does, and why.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: I hope that attendees will gain an understanding of how and why networking-calico provides IP-level connectivity between VMs, how this is different from other approaches such as the standard OVS and Linux Bridge ones, and when it might make sense for a particular deployment to use networking-calico.

videos.name: Networking-Calico, a Routing-Based Implementation of IP-Only Connectivity Between VMs - What, Why, How and the Future

schedule.title: A PaaS for Continuous Delivery of Cloud Native Apps. (minus Kubernetes and Mesos)
schedule.description:
Although there are variety of PaaS, enterprises require finer granularity and adaptability of development and deployment methodologies to existing practices and tools. Mesos, Kubernetes, etc. although popular still is IaaS albeit at a higher level of abstraction.

We'll take a fairly minimal openstack install and build a platform on top of it using standard open source tooling like Docker, Deis, etc. We will then take you through the application lifecycle of a cloud native application showing you how to use CI/CD on top of that platform and all you have to care about is your development workflow against github.

We will provide an environment with some tools integrated, requiring attendees to work on simple exercises and complement the platform with other tools and to follow the methodologies of continuous deployment. Once this is done, it can greatly simplify the development and deployment of applications and greatly reduce the time it takes to take a feature from idea to product.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Cloud Native Application Deployment requires integration of multiple tools that enterprises already use atop the OpenStack. Although there are variety of PaaS like Cloud Foundry, Open Shift, etc. Enterprises require finer granularity and adaptability of development and deployment methodologies to existing practices and tools. Mesos, Kubernetes, etc.  although popular still feel like IaaS albeit at a slightly higher level of abstraction.

We will provide an environment with some tools integrated, requiring attendees to work on simple exercises and complement the platform with other tools and to follow the methodologies of continuous deployment.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: You will walk away from this lab with the knowledge that Cloud Native Application Deployment requires integration of multiple tools atop the OpenStack. Once this is done, it can greatly simplify the development and deployment of applications and greatly reduce the time it takes to take a feature from idea to production and to do continuous integration and deployment.

videos.name: A PaaS for Continuous Delivery of Cloud Native Apps. (minus Kubernetes and Mesos)

schedule.title: Striving for a High-Performance NFV Grid on OpenStack. Why You, and Every OpenStack Community Member Should Be Excited About It.
schedule.description:
The idea of OpenStack as a vehicle to build, and operate NFV platforms is going mainstream. As it does, it continues to provide impetus to OpenStack ecosystem on numerous fronts. It is truly exciting to imagine the possibilities that open up as developers, users, architects, and operators push the performance, quality, and innovation in the ecosystem.

AT&T and other large service providers are driving efforts to make it possible to push 100 gigabit line rate on software switches, NUMA support among other things.

This session explores how the community as a whole benefits from rising NFV adoption. We then deep dive into DPI, and MEC as NFV use cases.

  • Technical overview of NFV related developments, and AT&T's innovations in OpenStack around this.
  • NUMA, SR-IOV, DPDK, RDMA - Why do they matter?
  • Use-case: Pushing the performance limit to achieve DPI capability on OpenStack.
  • Keys attributes of a high performing packet processing path.
  • The MEC (Mobile Edge Computing) use case.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed:
• We're narrating a story line about how the community as a whole benefits greatly from Telcos driving the NFV development and deployments.
  • Use-case of DPI (deep packet inspection) capability on OpenStack.
  • MEC use case.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• Overview about what NFV is and why it matters.
  • Technology overview of how NFV ties into overall OpenStack.
  • Attendees would learn about DPI and MEC use-case, and how they can get involved in NFV related efforts.

videos.name: Striving for a High-Performance NFV Grid on OpenStack. Why You, and Every OpenStack Community Member Should Be Excited About It.

schedule.title: Do Containers Become First Class Citizens in the Data Center? - Moderated by Cliff Grossner, Ph.D. IHS
schedule.description: Containers quickly rose in popularity among developers with standardization driving portability, and have led to new micro-segmented software architectures providing agility for solving large distributed computing tasks, such as big data analytics or motion picture rendering. What is the proper role for containers in the data center today? Do they become peers with virtual machines and bare metal computing and managed by the same platforms? Will they be deployed on all devices, such as servers, network adapter cards, network devices, etc? This panel will discuss the role containers will assume in the data center and how this important technology integrates with existing infrastructure in 2016 and beyond.
schedule.problem_addressed: Linux-based container technology is still nascent and expertise is scarce. However, architects and operators have to make design decisions for architectures that will persist for up to a decade. Although all the projects are open source, the most up to date information can be lost in a sea of information overload, and only the people directly contributing to the projects can keep up. By putting together a panel of experts, the moderator can guide the discussion and help operators make sense of what’s actionable today and what is possible tomorrow.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will be able to hear from the leading container experts in one sitting and understand how the role of containers in enterprise IT architecture so that they can make decisions about their own architectures going forward.

videos.name: Do Containers Become First Class Citizens in the Data Center? - Moderated by Cliff Grossner, Ph.D. IHS

schedule.title: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About OpenStack at Scale
schedule.description: A de facto guide to the scaling models, capabilities and limits of all OpenStack components. I will cover all core projects, their components and the limitations of each. In general, OpenStack scaling models fit into three categories: vertically scalable, horizontally scalable or sharded, which is a special case of horizontally scalable. Along with this overview I will take the opportunity to review structural details, future plans and past mistakes. Q&A should be a large part of this presentation. Please attend with lots of questions to ask.
schedule.problem_addressed:
1. To my knowledge, there is no guide to scaling OpenStack component by component. I will present this.

2. There are specific configurations of services that have significantly different scaling models, I will address these.

3. There are some problems with scalability that are well known, but the development efforts to correct them are not. I will discuss current development.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: What does and does not scale in OpenStack. What is being done to fix it. Pitfalls you can avoid.

videos.name: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About OpenStack at Scale

schedule.title: Tanks in The Clouds
schedule.description:
G-Core, a Luxembourg-based global IT solutions provider, has moved its G-Core Innovations IT infrastructure (DCs) to OpenStack from VMware. With Wargaming as a key client, this solution will support its military MMOs, with a multimillion user base, including World of Tanks and World of Warships.

When one says these games are popular, they mean that more than 1 million users are playing simultaneously (http://bit.ly/1TA5Ggw). To make that possible, G-Core provides Wargaming with more than 20 data centers (consisting of thousands of servers) all over the world.

G-Core has a huge and complex infrastructure to provide stable solutions, capable of enduring high loads. Using this experience, G-Core is able to find solutions and share expertise with other companies that require a competitive and robust service. This case study shows the huge, infrastructural move from VMware to OpenStack and describes the basic architectural solutions of the project.
schedule.problem_addressed:
The problem in this use case is the migration of a huge and complex infrastructure from VMware to OpenStack for an IaaS project.

G-Core has avoided cloud-based solutions, managing physical servers themselves and using VMware ESXi and OpenVZ containers. They also considered using Docker and Mesos as a container cluster management platform on top of OpenStack. All projects run in NFS and use Designate (DNSaaS). To start, G-Core deployed four clouds (two for tests and staging, two for pre-production and production) running in more than 100 physical servers in total.

G-Core's goal is to reduce time to market, providing users with self-service tools and, as a result, lessen the load on IT specialists. OpenStack is the right solution for this particular internal Automated Deployment Pipeline.

This case is interesting because it helps to view OpenStack at scale and from different perspectives: CI/CD and DevTest (QA), DevOps and applications, IT infrastructure administrators.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
• OpenStack vs VMware: Development, Testing and Production (independent investigation before decision making)
  • How to be successful in game promotion with OpenStack (from the horse’s mouth)
  • How to negotiate with this type of client (think big, start small): G-Core is a truly open source and DevOps oriented company. They use their own distro of Linux based on CentOS; Puppet and Fabric for software management; Git for code and script management and so on. They even wrote their own version of an app catalog in “Murano style”; they call it Realm Wizard.

videos.name: Tanks in The Clouds

schedule.title: A Pioneer's Vision of Networking
schedule.description: In this session, Guido Appenzeller---a founding member and pioneer of the revolution to virtualize the network---will share his vision on how networking is moving up the stack, and will discuss the role of OpenStack in this new age. The growing importance of public clouds, mobile devices, and multi-cloud strategies means that networking today is not about hardware but instead is about logical endpoints. The hard part is managing connectivity, compliance, and security in a scalable, policy-driven fashion. Come listen to this pioneer's vision of the future of networking and how that will impact OpenStack.
schedule.problem_addressed: This session addresses the rapid pace of change within the networking industry, and how both the networking industry and the OpenStack community need to evolve to address this rapid pace of change. OpenStack networks are only part of the overall solution that organizations need to address; they also need to address mobile devices, public cloud workloads, and multi-cloud architectures.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees can expect to learn more about the current state of networking and network virtualization, how network virtualization can (and should) expand to encompass public cloud workloads and mobile devices, and how managing policy---whether it's policy for connectivity or policy for security---is now one of the most critical emerging needs for today's organizations.

videos.name: A Pioneer's Vision of Networking

schedule.title: Newcomers Need You, How to Be A Good Mentor
schedule.description: You still remember the first time you've heard the word OpenStack, the efforts you had to make to wrap your head around it and to get your first patch merged. Now you know enough to be able to teach other people and put them up to speed. You would like to be a mentor but you are not sure about how time consuming it might be, you still have doubts and questions. In this session we will try to answer them. We will give advices based on our experience mentoring in the Outreachy and Google Summer of Code programs, suggest some strategies and list the most common mistakes a new mentor does.
schedule.problem_addressed: OpenStack community is growing a lot and we need people to step up as mentors, for the different internship programs we have and also for the newcomers we constantly see lurking on the main communication channels, to be able to scale. This session shows how anyone can be a mentor, core/PTL or not; and how it is a mutually benefiting experience. It includes all the information needed to find the right balance in the process of being a good mentor.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will learn different ways to mentor and will come out from this session with the right tools to help the community by enhancing the onboarding process. Also, they will learn about the different internship programs we have been running for a while now within OpenStack, precisely, Outreachy and Google Summer of Code.

videos.name: Newcomers Need You, How to Be A Good Mentor

schedule.title: How to Dismantle a Cloud to Use OpenStack
schedule.description: vBrownBag

schedule.title: Keystone: Work session
Heat: Work session
Manila: Work session
DPDK, Collectd & Ceilometer: The Missing Link Between My Telco Cloud and The NFV Infrastructure
schedule.description:
Collectd exposes statistics that facilitate more resilient and performant telco/NFV clouds.

It is vital to monitor systems for malfunctions that could lead to users’ application service disruption and promptly react to these fault events to facilitate improving overall system performance.

By providing Ceilometer with system statistics from collectd, there is more data available, which can be used for monitoring, performance analysis, fault detection, etc. using OPNFV Doctor-prescribed enhancements to OpenStack, action can then be taken to negate the effects of any faults in the deployment.

Gaps have been identified and work to improve OpenStack to enable a more fault tolerant cloud environment is well underway. A key part of this work includes expanding the amount of data available about the system (e.g. DPDK statistics), and improving alarming functionality in OpenStack Aodh.

 

The Telecom/NFV track is brought to you by OpenStack and OPNFV.
schedule.problem_addressed:
Medium-/large-scale cloud environments account for between hundreds and hundreds of thousands of infrastructure systems.  As the size of infrastructure and virtual resources grow, so does the effort of monitoring back-ends. Such conditions can cause crucial setbacks on the detection and the timely and efficient notification to cloud administrators.

One such example would be detecting and handling network issues for NFV deployments, and triggering alarms through OpenStack Aodh component.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt:
Attendees can expect to learn about:

  • Measuring and enforcing Traffic Quality Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) (Service Assurance) in OpenStack, including efforts to provide interfaces and functions in DPDK, collectd and OpenStack to support monitoring of resources in the NFVI such as network interfaces while a VNF is in service, including:
    - Exposing KPIs, monitoring the packet processing paths in DPDK and relaying the information to OpenStack.
    - Unlocking additional statistics via Collectd and interact with Ceilometer through collectd plug-ins, making existing statistics available quickly and easily.
    - Combining these components in a telemetry-enhanced platform
  • Notification and failover action enhancements undertaken by the Doctor project to essentially build an NFVI fault management and maintenance framework that supports Network Services high availability on top of the virtualized infrastructure
  • Next steps, use cases and how the community is committed to improving OpenStack in this area

videos.name: DPDK, Collectd & Ceilometer: The Missing Link Between My Telco Cloud and The NFV Infrastructure

Magnum: Unified Container Abstraction for Different COEs

OpenStack and the IoT: Where We Stand, Where We're Going, What We Need to Get There
schedule.description: The Internet of Things (IoT), with its multitude of devices making calls to applications, is a perfect use case for the scalable, adaptable environment that is OpenStack. But that doesn't mean that we're ready -- not by a long shot. In this panel, a group of application developers, network engineers, and security experts will look at what OpenStack can already accomplish, and what needs to happen in order for OpenStack to fulfill its potential.
schedule.problem_addressed: The Internet of Things (IoT), with its multitude of devices making calls to applications, is a perfect use case for the scalable, adaptable environment that is OpenStack. But that doesn't mean that we're ready -- not by a long shot. In this panel, a group of application developers, network engineers, and security experts will look at what OpenStack can already accomplish, and what needs to happen in order for OpenStack to fulfill its potential.
schedule.attendees_expected_learnt: Attendees will leave this session with a better understanding of the capabilities of OpenStack when it comes to IoT applications, how to mitigate issues in places where it may still be lacking, and what can be done to ensure that OpenStack can become the premiere platform for development of these applications.

videos.name: OpenStack and the IoT: Where We Stand, Where We're Going, What We Need to Get There
